    Alarm system means any mechanism, equipment or device which is designed or used for the detection of an unauthorized entry into a building, structure, facility or enclosed area or for alerting others to the commission of an unlawful act or a fire within a building, structure, facility or enclosed area or both and which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when activated; this definition shall include local alarm systems. 
    Alarm user means any natural person who is in control of any building structure or facility wherein an alarm system is installed operated or maintained. 
    Board means the board of public works and safety of the city. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm system eliciting a response by the police or fire department of the city, which is not in response to actual or threatened danger to persons or damage to property. The term "false alarm" also means the activation of any such alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or maintenance, or negligence of the alarm user or his employees or agents; but it does not include alarm activation caused by violent conditions of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by an alarm user or alarm system installer or service. 
    Local alarm system means a signaling system which when activated causes an audible and/or visible signaling device to be activated only in or on the premises in which the system is installed, operated or maintained. 
    Notice means written notice either by certified mail, return receipt requested or by personal service upon the addressee at his last known address. 
(Code 1985, § 93.51; Ord. No. 3372, 5-7-1990) 
Sec. 38-49. - Response to alarm; determination of validity. 
(a)  Whenever an alarm system is activated in the city which results in an emergency response to the premises by its police or fire department, the officer on the scene of the activated alarm system shall inspect the area protected by the system and shall determine whether the emergency response was required or was a false alarm. 
(b)  If the officer at the scene of the activated alarm system determines the alarm to be false, the officer shall make a report of the false alarm, notice of which shall be sent to the alarm user at the address of the premises or at the last known address of the alarm user, if different from the premises address. 
(c)  The police chief or fire chief or his designee shall have the right to inspect the premises to which a response has been made and may cause such inspection to be made at any reasonable time after the occurrence of a false alarm. 
(Code 1985, § 93.52; Ord. No. 3372, 5-7-1990) 
Sec. 38-50. - False alarm. 
(a)  Whenever an alarm user issues, causes to be issued, or permits the issuance of a false alarm, this section shall apply; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to a residential alarm user who is a natural person aged 65 or older. 
(b)  The police and fire departments of the city shall maintain appropriate records of all false alarms to which each department responds. After a department responds to three false alarms at a location on or after January 1 and before December 31 of any calendar year, the department which responded to the scene of a false alarm shall issue fines in accordance with section 1-7. 
(Code 1985, § 93.53; Ord. No. 3372, 5-7-1990) 
Sec. 38-51. - Automatic telephone dialing systems prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, install, maintain, lease, operate, or assist in the operation of an automatic telephone dialing alarm system over any telephone lines, exclusively used by the public, to directly request emergency service from the police department or the fire department of the city. 
(b)  The police chief or the fire chief or his designee upon receiving knowledge of an automatic telephone dialing system installed or operated in violation of this section shall order, in writing, the owner operator, or lessee to disconnect and cease operation of the system within 72 hours of receipt of the order. 
(c)  Facilities which are owned or operated by the city or the city utilities are excluded from any prohibition contained in this section. 
(Code 1985, § 93.54; Ord. No. 3372, 5-7-1990; Ord. No. 4115, 11-18-1997) 
Sec. 38-52. - Alarm silencer required. 
    No local alarm system and no alarm system shall be installed on any premises in the city which does not have an operable automatic resetting device to silence the alarm audible sounder within 30 minutes after activation and to prevent the alarm sounding again as a result of the same event that caused the original activator. 
(Code 1985, § 93.55; Ord. No. 3372, 5-7-1990) 
Sec. 38-53. - Manual fire alarm signaling devices. 
    When manual fire alarm signaling devices are installed and are not directly connected to the fire department or monitored by a 24-hour security service, a permanent sign shall be installed at each actuating device. These signs shall read as follows: 
IN CASE OF FIRE 
Pull this alarm 
Telephone the fire department 9-1-1 
(Code 1985, § 93.56; Ord. No. 3372, 5-7-1990) 
Sec. 38-54. - Abatement. 
    Any alarm system installed, operated or maintained in violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be abated in the manner as nuisances are now or may hereafter be abated under existing law. 
(Code 1985, § 93.59; Ord. No. 3372, 5-7-1990) 
Chapter 42 - HUMAN RELATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1-42-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Indiana Fair Housing, IC 22-9.5-1-1 et seq.; Indiana civil rights enforcement, IC 22-9-1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 42-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agent means any natural person or agent thereof, who, with or without a fee or other valuable consideration, offers, sells, purchases, exchanges, rents, or negotiates, for the sale, purchase, exchange, or rental of the real property of another, or holds himself or herself out as engaged in the business of selling, purchasing, exchanging, or renting the real property of another, or collects rental for the use of the real property of another. 
    Aggrieved person means any person who claims to have been injured by a discriminatory housing practice; or believes that he will be injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur. 
    Board means the board of public works and safety of the city, or its designee. The use of the term "board of public works and safety" is also meant to include the designee of the board of public works and safety. 
    Complainant means any individual charging on his own behalf to have been personally aggrieved by a discriminatory practice in connection with a housing accommodation. 
    Discriminate or discrimination means the exclusion from, or failure or refusal to extend to a person, equal opportunities because of sex, race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, handicap, or familial status, of the buyer, renter, or applicant, or to increase the selling price or rent of any housing accommodation because of the sex, race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, handicap, or familial status, of the buyer, renter, or applicant. 
    Dwelling means any building, structure, or part of a building or structure that is occupied as, or designed or intended for occupancy as, a residency by one or more families; or any vacant land that is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location of a building, structure, or part of a building or structure described by subdivision. 
    Family includes a single individual. 
    Financial institution means any bank, credit union, insurance company, or savings and loan association or other entity or organization that makes or purchases loans or provides other financial assistance that operates or has a place of business in the city. 
    Handicap means, with respect to a person: 
(1)  A physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of the person's major life activities; a record of having an impairment as described above; or being regarded as having an impairment as described above. The term does not include current illegal use of or addiction to a controlled substance (as defined in section 102 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 USC 802). The term does not include an individual solely because that individual is a transvestite. 
(2)  In reference to housing under this chapter, the term "handicap" or "handicapped" also means the physical or mental condition of a person which constitutes a substantial disability unrelated to the person's ability to acquire, rent, or maintain a housing accommodation. 
    Housing accommodation includes any building, structure, or portion thereof located within the territorial limits of the city, which is used or occupied, or is maintained, arranged or designed to be used or occupied as a home, residence, or sleeping place of one or more human beings; and any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location thereon of any building, structure, or portion thereof. 
    Loan includes, but is not limited to, the providing of funds for consideration, which are sought for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing, or maintaining a housing accommodation as that term is defined herein; or secured by residential real estate. 
    Owner means the person holding legal or equitable title to property, or his legal representative. 
    Owner/occupant means any individual who is a titleholder of record or contract purchaser of the real property in question and who, in addition, continues to occupy and reside in the property as his principal dwelling place at the time the alleged discriminatory act occurs. 
    Person includes one or more individuals, partnerships, associations, organizations, corporations, cooperatives, legal representatives, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers, lending institutions, and other organized groups or persons. 
    Restrictive covenants includes every condition, restriction, or prohibition, including right of re-entry or possibility of reverter which, directly or indirectly, limits the use or occupancy of real property on the basis of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. A restrictive covenant shall not apply to the limitation of use on the basis of religion of real property held by a religious institution or organization or by a religious or charitable organization operated, supervised, or controlled by a religious institution or organization, and used for religious or charitable purposes. 
    Steering means the influencing or attempting to influence by words or acts the choice or location of housing of a prospective purchaser, occupant, or tenant, in connection with viewing, buying, leasing, or occupying real estate based on sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status, so as to promote or maintain segregation. 
    Unlawful housing practice means the commission of any act prohibited by section 42-21. 
    Varying term includes, but is not limited to, the following practices: requiring a greater down payment than is usual for the particular type of loan involved; requiring a shorter period of amortization than is usual for the particular type of loan involved; charging a higher interest rate than is usual for the particular type of loan involved; and under-appraisal of real estate or other item of property offered as security. 
(Code 1985, § 103.02; Ord. No. 3588, 5-4-1992) 
Sec. 42-20. - Declaration of policy. 
(a)  In furthering the policy of the state as expressed in its constitution and other laws; to further the declared policy of the city to assure full and equal opportunity to all residents, regardless of sex, race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry, handicap, age or familial status, to live in decent, sanitary, and healthful living quarters, in order that the peace, health, safety, and general welfare of all the inhabitants of the city may be protected and ensured; it is declared that owners, or agents for owners, be regulated to the end to prohibit discrimination in housing by any owners or agents of owners. 
(b)  It is further declared to be the policy of the city that in the spirit of pursuing a common purpose, the common council and the board of public works and safety shall endeavor to work and cooperate with all owners or agents for owners who are, or may be, doing business in the city to implement the declared purpose of this article, to ensure the opportunity for all persons to live in decent housing facilities without discrimination because of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, age or familial status of such persons, and to accomplish the same in an orderly, lawful, proper, and responsible fashion. 
(Code 1985, § 103.01; Ord. No. 3588, 5-4-1992) 
Sec. 42-21. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or agent for owner, or any other person to: 
(1)  Publish or circulate, or cause to be published or circulated, any notice, statement, or advertisement, or to adopt a policy or to use any form of application for the purchase, lease, rental or financing of a housing accommodation which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation or discrimination as to sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(2)  Discriminate in the sales price or rent of any housing accommodation, or to discriminate in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental in the provision of services or facilities for any housing accommodation. 
(3)  Discriminate or participate in discrimination in connection with lending, guaranteeing of loans, or the making available of funds for the purchase, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, or improvement of any housing facility. 
(4)  Solicit for sale or lease any housing accommodation, or distribute, or cause to be distributed, written representation with the specific intent of inducing any owner of any housing accommodation to sell or lease his property because of the alleged loss of value of property because of the anticipated presence of persons of any particular sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status in any neighborhood. 
(5)  Refuse to sell or rent, to refuse in the showing or making available for inspection, sale or rent, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of any housing accommodation; or to falsely represent that a dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when the housing accommodation is in fact available, to any prospective buyer or renter, because of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(6)  Deny a person access to or membership or participation in multiple-listing services, real estate brokers' organizations, or other similar services because of sex, race, color, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(7)  Delay the processing or denying of a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing, or maintaining a dwelling, or to discriminate in the fixing of that amount, interest rate, duration, or other financial assistance because of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(8)  Discriminate in appraising the value of real estate or in the sale of insurance in connection with a real estate transaction because of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(9)  Enter into a listing agreement which discriminates against any person because of sex, race, color, religion, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(10)  Solicit with the intention of creating or maintaining a segregated environment by including or excluding a person because of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status, any owner to sell or rent or list residential property at any time after the person has notice that the owner does not desire to sell, rent, or list the residential property. For the purpose of this division, notice must be provided as follows: 
a.  The notice may be given by the owner personally or by a third party in the owner's name, either in the form of an individual notice or a list, provided it complies with the provisions subsection (a)(10)b of this section. 
b.  The notice shall be explicit as to whether each owner on the notice seeks to avoid both solicitation for listing and sale, or only for listing, or only for sale, as well as the period of time which any avoidance is desired. The notice shall be dated and either of the following shall apply: 
1.  Each owner shall have signed the notice; 
2.  The person or entity preparing the notice shall provide an accompanying affidavit to the effect that all the names on the notice are, in fact, genuine as to the identity of the person listed and that the persons have requested not to be solicited as indicated. 
c.  The individual notice in the form of a list with the accompanying affidavit shall be served personally or by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. 
(11)  Intentionally create alarm among residents of any community by transmitting communication in any manner, including a telephone call whether or not conversation ensues, with a design to induce any owner of residential real estate in this city to sell or lease his property because of any present or prospective entry into the vicinity of the property involved of any person of any particular sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(12)  Insert or include in a written instrument relating to housing accommodations any condition, restriction, or prohibition which would constitute a restrictive covenant within the meaning of this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is not a bona fide prospective buyer or renter or his agent to offer purchase or lease, or to participate in the purchase or leasing of any housing accommodation because of sex, race, color, religion, handicap, familial status, national origin or ancestry for the purpose of including or provoking an owner or his agent to commit any of the other unlawful acts contained in this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any financial institution, on the grounds of unlawful discrimination, to: 
(1)  Deny any person any of the services normally offered by the institution; 
(2)  Provide any person with any service which is different from, or provided in a different manner than, that which is provided to other persons similarly situated; 
(3)  Deny or vary the terms of the loan; 
(4)  Deny or vary the terms of loan on the basis that a specific parcel of real estate offered as security is located in a specific geographical area; 
(5)  Deny or vary the terms of a loan without having considered all of the regular and dependable income of each person who would be liable for repayment of the loan; or 
(6)  Utilize lending standards that have no economic basis and which constitute unlawful discrimination. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person, or for two or more persons, to conspire to: 
(1)  Retaliate against a person because he has opposed that which he reasonably and in good faith has made a charge, filed a complaint, testified, assisted, or participated in an investigation, proceeding, or hearing under this chapter. 
(2)  Aid, abet, compel, or coerce a person to commit any violation of this chapter; 
(3)  Willfully interfere with the performance of a duty or the exercise of a power by the board or its designee, or one of its members or representatives or the investigator, director, or one of its officers or employees; or 
(4)  Coerce, intimidate, threaten, or interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of, or on account of that person having aided or encouraged any other person in the exercise or enjoyment of, any right granted or protected by this chapter. 
(e)  As applied to any handicapped person, it shall be unlawful: 
(1)  To refuse to permit, at the expense of the handicapped person, reasonable modifications of existing premises occupied or to be occupied by the person if the modifications may be necessary to afford the person full enjoyment of the premises; except that, in the case of a rental, the landlord may, where it is reasonable to do so, condition permission for modification on the renter agreeing to restore the interior of the premises to the condition that existed before the modification, reasonable wear and tear excepted; 
(2)  To refuse to make reasonable accommodations in rules, policies, practices, or services, when the accommodations may be necessary to afford the person equal opportunity to use and enjoy a dwelling; or 
(3)  In connection with the design and construction of covered multifamily dwellings for first occupancy after the enactment of this chapter, to fail to design and construct those things in a manner that: 
a.  The public-use and common-use portions of the dwellings are readily accessible to and usable by handicapped persons; 
b.  All the doors designed to allow passage into and within all premises within the dwellings are sufficiently wide to allow passage by handicapped persons in wheelchairs; 
c.  All premises within the dwellings contain the following features of adaptive design: 
1.  An accessible route into and through the dwelling; 
2.  Light switches, electrical switches, thermostats, and other environmental controls in accessible locations; 
3.  Reinforcements in bathroom walls to allow the later installation of grab bars; 
4.  Usable kitchens and bathrooms in which an individual in a wheel chair can maneuver about the space. 
Compliance with the appropriate requirements of the American National Standard for buildings and facilities providing accessibility and usability for physically handicapped people satisfies the requirements of subsection (e)(3)c.3 of this section. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the commission of a discriminatory act because of familial status. Under this chapter, a discriminatory act is committed because of familial status if the act is committed because the person who is subject to discrimination is: 
(1)  Pregnant; 
(2)  Domiciled with an individual younger than 18 years of age in regard to whom the person: 
a.  Is the parent or legal custodian; 
b.  Has the written permission of the parent or legal custodian for domicile with that person; or 
(3)  In the process of obtaining legal custody of an individual younger than 18 years of age. 
(Code 1985, § 103.03; Ord. No. 3588, 5-4-1992) 
Sec. 42-22. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the following practices and transactions: 
(1)  Any real estate broker, real estate salesman, or owner from imposing any and all conditions and requirements relative to any of the transactions described in this chapter, provided the conditions do not concern sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status and provided the conditions are imposed uniformly, regardless of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap or familial status. 
(2)  The owner, lessor, or sublessor of real property of any real estate broker or real estate salesman or agent or corporation engaged in real estate transactions from exercising absolute discretion in establishing the terms and conditions of sale, exchange, lease, or rental of real property or in any transactions involving real property, providing the terms do not concern sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(3)  An owner, lessor, or sublessor of real property from selling or renting the same without first offering the property to the public at large. 
(4)  Any sale or rental of a single-family home by its owner so long as the following criteria are met: 
a.  The owner does not own or have beneficial interest in more than three single-family homes at the time of the sale or rental; 
b.  The owner or a member of his family was the last current resident of the home; 
c.  The home is sold or rented without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities or services of any real estate broker or salesman, or of any employee or agent of any real estate broker or salesman; 
d.  The home is sold or rented without publication, posting or mailing, after notice, of any advertisement or written notice in violation of this chapter; 
e.  The sale or rental of rooms or units in a dwelling containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four families living independently of each other if the owner maintains and occupies one of the living quarters as the owner's residence. 
(5)  A religious organization, association, or society or a nonprofit institution or organization, operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association, or society from limiting the sale, rental, or occupancy of a dwelling which it owns or operates for other than commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to the persons, unless membership in the religion is restricted on account of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(6)  This article does not prohibit a private club not open to the public that, as an incident to the club's primary purpose, provides lodging that the club owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose from limiting the rental or occupancy of that lodging to the members or from giving preference to the members, unless membership in the club is restricted because of race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(7)  A financial institution from considering sound underwriting practices and contemplation of any loan to any person. Such practices shall include: the willingness and the financial ability of the borrower to repay the loan; the market value of any real estate or other property proposed as security for a loan; or diversification of the financial institution's investment portfolio. 
(8)  This article shall not prohibit certain considerations for housing for older persons: 
a.  Pertaining to housing for older persons, the board shall develop regulations which require at least the following factors: 
1.  The existence of significant facilities and services specifically designed to meet the physical or social needs of the older persons; 
2.  That at least 80 percent of the units are occupied by at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit; 
3.  The publication of, or an adherence to, policies and procedures which demonstrate an intent by the owner or manager to provide housing for persons 55 years of age or older. 
b.  As used in this section, the term "housing for older persons" means housing: 
1.  That the board determines is specifically designed and operated to assist elderly persons under a federal or state program; 
2.  That is intended for and solely occupied by persons at least 62 years of age; or 
3.  That is intended and operated for occupancy by persons at least 55 years of age in each unit as determined by board rules. 
c.  The provisions of this article relating to familial status do not apply to housing for older persons. 
d.  Housing shall not fail to meet the requirements for housing for older persons by reason of: 
1.  Persons residing in the housing as of the date of enactment of this article who do not meet the age requirements described in subsection (8) of this section, provided that new occupants of the housing meet the age requirements of this division; 
2.  Unoccupied units, provided that the units are reserved for occupancy by persons who meet the age requirements of this division. 
(9)  Appraisals of property do not prohibit a person engaged in the business of furnishing appraisal of real property from taking into consideration factors other than sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. 
(10)  Health and safety restrictions do not affect reasonable local or state restriction on the maximum number of occupants permitted to occupy a dwelling or restriction relating to health or safety standards, nor affect a requirement of nondiscrimination in any other state or federal law. 
(Code 1985, § 103.04; Ord. No. 3588, 5-4-1992) 
Sec. 42-23. - Limitations and permissible acts. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting any real estate broker, real estate salesman, owner or agent for an owner, or any other person from imposing any and all conditions and requirements relative to any of the transactions described in this article provided the conditions do not concern sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status, and provided the conditions are imposed uniformly, regardless of sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the owner, lessor, or sublessor of real property, or any real estate broker or real estate salesman or agent or corporation engaged in real estate transactions, from exercising absolute discretion in establishing the terms, and conditions of the sale, exchange, lease, or rental of real property or in any transactions involving real property, provided the terms and conditions do not concern sex, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, handicap, or familial status. Nothing in this article shall be construed as requiring an owner, lessor, or sublessor of real property to offer the property to the public at large before selling or renting the same. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit conduct against a person because the person has been convicted by any court of competent jurisdiction of the illegal manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance as defined in Section 102 of the United States Controlled Substance Acts, 21 USC 802. 
(Code 1985, § 103.05; Ord. No. 3588, 5-4-1992) 
Sec. 42-24. - Board of public works and safety to enforce. 
    The board of public works and safety or its designee is given the powers and duties to enforce this chapter. The board is empowered to carry out the functions and duties so designated under the provisions of this article and it shall be the duty of the board to: 
(1)  Receive, record and investigate complaints charging any unlawful housing practice. 
(2)  Seek conciliation of parties involved in the complaints by conciliation, conferences, hold hearings where necessary, make findings of fact, issue recommendations and orders, including orders rejecting any claims that may be, in the opinion of the board, without merit, and publish its findings in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Hold hearings, subpoena witnesses, compel their attendance, administer oaths, take testimony of any person under oath and require the production for examination of all books and papers relating to any matter under investigation or in question before the board. 
(Code 1985, § 103.06; Ord. No. 3588, 5-4-1992) 
Sec. 42-25. - Enforcement procedure. 
(a)  The board of public works and safety shall adopt the rules and regulations as may be necessary to carry out the purpose and provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by any violation of any provision of this article may file with the board a written complaint under oath setting forth his grievance. The complaint shall state the name and address of the complainant and of the person against whom the complaint is brought and shall also state the alleged facts surrounding the alleged violation of this chapter. Complaints must be filed alleging violations of this article to the board within 30 days after the date of the alleged violation. 
(c)  On receipt of any complaint involving a discriminatory practice, the board shall determine the facts, and if there appears to be probable cause for complaint the board shall use its office to attempt an adjustment by education, conciliation and conference. No more than 90 days shall be allowed for this purpose. 
(d)  If in the opinion of a majority of the board the efforts to settle any complaint by the means enumerated in subsection (c) of this section have not adjusted the specific complaint, the board shall cause a public hearing to be held. A notice of the hearing, including the particulars of the complaint, shall be sent to the respondent by registered mail not less than ten days prior to the day set for hearing. The hearing may be conducted before the board at a duly convened meeting, or the hearing may be conducted before a hearing officer appointed by the board, which hearing officer shall be a member of the county bar association. Hearings conducted before the board, or a hearing officer, shall be conducted in an informal manner and without recourse to the technical common-law rules of evidence required in proceedings in judicial courts, and such manner of proof and introduction of evidence shall be deemed sufficient and shall govern the proof and decision of all questions of fact, if substantial, reliable and probative evidence supports the board's determination. The board shall, as a matter of policy, provide for the exclusion of irrelevant, immaterial or unduly repetitious evidence. Every person who is a party to the proceedings shall have the right to appear in person or by counsel, to submit evidence in open hearing and shall have the right of cross-examination. The hearings shall be held in the city hall. 
(e)  In the event of such hearing before a hearing officer, as herein set forth, the recommendation of the hearing officer, together with the complete file, shall be submitted to and filed with the board. The board may hear additional evidence or refer it back to the hearing officer to hear additional evidence. The board may adopt the recommendation of the hearing officer, amend or modify the same, or may make the order or determination as is proper on the record. 
(f)  The respondent shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and appear at the hearing to testify in his own behalf, or to be represented by counsel or otherwise, and to examine and cross examine witnesses. 
(g)  If upon all the evidence taken, no unlawful practice is found to have been committed, the case shall be dismissed and the parties involved so notified. 
(h)  If upon all the evidence taken, the board by a majority vote shall determine that the respondent committed the discriminatory practice set forth in the complaint, the board may issue an order directing the respondent to cease and desist the discriminatory practice so found to be engaged in. 
(i)  The board is empowered to prevent any person from discharging, expelling, or otherwise discriminating against any other person because the person filed a complaint or testified in any hearing before the board or in any way assisted in any matter under investigation. 
(j)  The board is empowered to issue a temporary emergency order against any person requiring the person to do an act preserving the possibility of a remedy for a complaint or to refrain from doing an act damaging the possibility of a remedy during the investigation of the complaint; provided, however: 
(1)  That no emergency order shall be issued unless a time and place for hearing on the temporary order is designated in the order. 
(2)  That the hearing on the temporary emergency order shall be held within ten days following the issuance of the temporary order, unless continued by the board at the request of the respondent. At the hearing, the complainant shall show that a failure to continue the temporary order would damage a remedy. 
(k)  The board may certify the case and the entire record of its proceedings to the city department of law, which shall invoke the aid of an appropriate court to impose legal or equitable relief. 
(Code 1985, § 103.07; Ord. No. 3588, 5-4-1992) 
Chapter 46 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
(a)  Curfew. The custodial parent or legal guardian of any child who commits a curfew violation, as defined herein, shall be subject to the following fines: 
(1)  Twenty-five dollars for a first offense, plus court costs; 
(2)  One hundred dollars for a second offense within a one-year period, plus court costs; or 
(3)  Two hundred dollars for a third offense and every subsequent offense within a one-year period, plus court costs. 
(b)  Alcoholic beverages. An officer of the city police department may issue a city ordinance violation citation to a person who violates sections 46-108 or 46-109. The first citation issued to an individual shall impose a $50.00 fine. Each subsequent citation issued to an individual shall impose a penalty not less than $100.00 and not more than $2,500.00. 
(c)  Provisions where no penalty specified. Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no penalty is specified shall be subject to such penalties as are provided in section 1-7. 
(d)  Ultimate fighting. Any person found in violation of any provision of article VI of this chapter shall be fined not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for each violation. Every day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1985, § 132.99; Ord. No. 4263, 4-6-1998; Ord. No. 3578, 3-2-1992; Ord. No. 4397, 6-7-1999) 
Sec. 46-2. - Accosting persons prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to accost, approach, or signal any person of the opposite sex unknown to that person and by any word, sign, or gesture, attempt to speak to or to become acquainted with that person against his will on any public street or in any public place or in any place in the city, except in the transaction of legitimate business or to extend greetings of the day to that person. 
(Code 1968, tit. 10, § 1; Code 1985, § 130.01; Ord. No. 1022, 10-16-1950) 
Sec. 46-3. - Loitering; loafing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any persons to assemble, except at a public meeting of the citizens, on any of the sidewalks, streets, street corners, or near the mouths of alleys of the city, to the obstruction thereof, or so as to hinder, delay, or annoy persons passing in, upon, or along them, or the owner or occupants or property adjacent thereto; or for any persons so assembled to make personal remarks to passersby for the purpose of annoying them. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any member of the police force to issue a citation to any person found to be in violation of this section. That citation shall carry a penalty of $25.00. 
(Code 1968, tit. 290, § 4; Code 1985, § 132.01; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906; Ord. No. 3977, 9-25-1995) 
Sec. 46-4. - Spitting on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit on any sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1968, tit. 290, § 5; Code 1985, § 132.02; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 46-5. - Shooting within city limits prohibited. 
    No person shall throw or shoot missiles of any kind by means of a bow, sling, gun; or throw or shoot a projectile of any character whatever within the limits of the city, except as provided in this Code. 
(Code 1968, tit. 200, § 1; Code 1985, § 132.20; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906; Ord. No. 4171, 5-19-1997) 
Sec. 46-6. - Vile or indecent language. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to utter or use vile or indecent language or language involving moral turpitude in the presence or hearing of any person on any public street, or in any public place. 
(Code 1968, tit. 10 § 2; Code 1985, § 133.01; Ord. No. 1022, 10-16-1950) 
Sec. 46-7. - Enticement to commit unlawful acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to entice or procure a person of the opposite sex to commit any unlawful act, or to accost, approach, or signal any person, and by word, sign, or gesture suggest or invite any person to any building, vehicle, conveyance, or premises, except in the transaction of legitimate business. 
(Code 1968, tit. 10, § 3; Code 1985, § 133.02; Ord. No. 1022, 10-16-1950) 
Secs. 46-8-46-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CURFEW 

Sec. 46-31. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  It is a curfew violation for a child 15, 16 or 17 years of age to be in or remain at a public place within the city: 
(1)  Between 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on Saturday or Sunday; 
(2)  After 11:00 p.m. on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday; or 
(3)  Before 5:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday. 
(b)  It is a curfew violation for a child less than 15 years of age to be in a public place after 11:00 p.m. or before 5:00 a.m. on any day. 
(Code 1985, § 132.10; Ord. No. 4263, 4-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-32. - Exceptions to section 46-31. 
    Section 46-31 shall not apply to a child who is: 
(1)  Accompanied by a child's parent, guardian, or custodian; 
(2)  Accompanied by an adult specified by the child's parent, guardian, or custodian; 
(3)  Performing an emergency errand at the written direction of the child's parent, guardian or custodian; or 
(4)  Participating in, going to, or returning home from: 
a.  Lawful employment; 
b.  School-sanctioned activity; 
c.  A religious event; or 
d.  An activity sponsored by a civic or public organization or an event which directly involves the child's rights of free speech or assembly protected by the United States Constitution. 
(5)  Engaged in interstate or intrastate vehicular travel; 
(6)  On the sidewalk of the place where such child resides, or on the sidewalk of either next-door neighbor not communicating an objection to the police officer. 
(Code 1985, § 132.11; Ord. No. 4263, 4-6-1998; Ord. No. 4508, 8-21-2000) 
Sec. 46-33. - Cemetery curfew for minors. 
(a)  It is a curfew violation for a child 15, 16 or 17 years of age to be on property used as a cemetery or on other property used to memorialize the dead: 
(1)  Between 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. on Saturday or Sunday; 
(2)  After 7:00 p.m. on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday; or 
(3)  Before 5:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday. 
(b)  It is a curfew violation for a child under 15 years of age to be on property used as a cemetery or other property used to memorialize the dead after 7:00 p.m. or before 5:00 a.m. on any day. 
(c)  Notwithstanding subsections (a) and (b) of this section, a child may be lawfully on cemetery property or other property used to memorialize the dead if accompanied by a parent, guardian, custodian or an adult specified by the minor's parent, guardian or custodian. 
(Code 1985, § 132.12; Ord. No. 4263, 4-6-1998) 
Secs. 46-34-46-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ABANDONED REFRIGERATORS OR SIMILAR CONTAINERS 

Sec. 46-55. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airtight door or airtight lock means any door which is tight enough so as not to leave sufficient air to enter, making it possible for any person confined to suffocate. The fact that a person has suffocated after being confined in any such ice box, refrigerator, or other container shall be prima facie evidence that the door or lock was airtight. Any attachment to release a door from the inside must be of sufficient construction so as to be accessible and easily released by children. 
(Code 1968, tit. 240, § 3; Code 1985, § 132.30; Ord. No. 1073, 10-19-1953) 
Sec. 46-56. - Abandonment prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling, or in any uninhabited building or dwelling in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended, or discarded ice box, refrigerator, or any other container of any kind which has an airtight door or lock, or other such device thereon, which may not be released for opening from the inside of the ice box, refrigerator, or container. 
(Code 1968, tit. 240, § 1; Code 1985, § 132.31; Ord. No. 1073, 10-19-1953) 
Sec. 46-57. - Locks, doors to be removed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building, dwelling, or in any uninhabited building or dwelling, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended, or discarded ice box or any other container of any kind whatsoever which has an airtight door or snap-lock or other such device thereon, without first removing the snap-lock, doors, or other such device thereon from the ice box, refrigerator, or container. 
(Code 1968, tit. 240, § 2; Code 1985, § 132.32; Ord. No. 1073, 10-19-1953) 
Secs. 46-58-46-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIREWORKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of fireworks, IC 22-11-14-1 et seq. 

Sec. 46-88. - Supervised public display. 
    Every fireworks display shall be handled by a qualified operator to be approved by the chief of the fire department and shall be so located, discharged, or fired as, in the opinion of the chief of the fire department, after proper inspection, to not be hazardous to persons or property. 
(Code 1985, § 132.40) 
Sec. 46-89. - Certificates of insurance required for supervised public display; amount and conditions. 
    The common council shall require a certificate of insurance conditioned for the payment of all damages which may be caused either to a person in an amount of not less than $10,000.00 and to property in an amount of not less than $10,000.00, by reason of the licensed display, and arising from any acts of the licensee, his agents, employees, or subcontractors. The common council may, in its discretion, require additional amounts of insurance coverage not to exceed $100,000.00 for damages caused to a person, or $100,000.00 for damage to property. 
(Code 1985, § 132.41) 
Sec. 46-90. - Consumer fireworks. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consumer fireworks shall be defined as in IC 22-11-14-1. 
(b)  Prohibited with city limits; exceptions. No person may use, ignite, or discharge consumer fireworks within the city limits except during the following times: 
(1)  Between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and two hours after sunset on June 29, June 30, July 1, July 2, July 3, July 5, July 6, July 7, July 8, and July 9. 
(2)  Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on July 4. 
(3)  Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on December 31 and 1:00 a.m. on January 1. 
(c)  Prohibited on public streets, parks, or other public lands. No person may use, ignite, or discharge consumer fireworks on any public street or alley, in any public park, or any other public land within the city limits at any time. 
(d)  Igniting or discharging on private property. Any person using, igniting, or discharging consumer fireworks from private property must have permission of the property's owner. 
(e)  Violations of section; penalty. Violations of this section shall be subject to fines issued through the ordinance violation bureau, except that in instances where a violation results in a fire and damage is determined to be caused by negligence or willful disregard of this section, a fine equal to the cost expended by the city to respond shall be assessed. In no case shall the fine exceed $2,500.00 for the first such incident or $7,500.00 for subsequent incidents. 
(Ord. No. 5111, § 1, 7-2-2007) 
Secs. 46-91-46-106. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OPEN ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Public intoxication, IC 7.1-5-1-3; intoxication upon common carrier, IC 7.1-5-1-6. 

Sec. 46-107. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic beverage has the meaning set forth in IC 7.1-1-3-5. 
    Container has the meaning set forth in IC 7.1-1-3-13. 
    Motor vehicle has the meaning set forth in IC 9-13-2-105, except that the term "motor vehicle," as used in this article, shall not include recreational vehicles, as defined in IC 9-13-2-150, and is designed to transport more than ten passengers including the operator, or any chartered passenger vehicle licensed to operate within the state. 
(Code 1985, § 132.50; Ord. No. 3578, 3-2-1992) 
Sec. 46-108. - Possession or consumption prohibited. 
    A person who knowingly: 
(1)  Consumes an alcoholic beverage; 
(2)  Possesses a container: 
a.  That has been opened; 
b.  That has a broken seal; or 
c.  From which some of the contents have been removed; 
while in a motor vehicle that is being operated on a public highway within the city limits commits a violation of this article constituting an ordinance violation. 
(Code 1985, § 132.51; Ord. No. 3578, 3-2-1992) 
Sec. 46-109. - Operator or owner of motor vehicle in violation. 
(a)  The operator or owner of a motor vehicle who, while the motor vehicle is in operation, knowingly keeps or allows to be kept in an area of the motor vehicle that is accessible to the operator or a passenger a container: 
(1)  That has been opened; 
(2)  That has a broken seal; or 
(3)  From which some of the contents have been removed; 
commits a violation of this article constituting an ordinance violation. 
(b)  The operator of a recreational vehicle or chartered passenger vehicle licensed to operate within the state, who, while the motor vehicle is in operation, knowingly keeps or allows to be kept in an area of the recreational vehicle or chartered passenger vehicle that is accessible to the operator a container: 
(1)  That has been opened; 
(2)  That has a broken seal; or 
(3)  From which some of the contents have been removed; 
commits a violation of this article constituting an ordinance violation. 
(Code 1985, § 132.52; Ord. No. 3578, 3-2-1992) 
Sec. 46-110. - Signs. 
    Signs giving notice of the prohibition of open alcoholic beverage containers shall be posted giving notice of the regulations at all locations deemed appropriate by the city engineer or his designee. 
(Code 1985, § 132.53; Ord. No. 3578, 3-2-1992) 
Secs. 46-111-46-133. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ULTIMATE FIGHTING 

Sec. 46-134. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bodily injury means any impairment of physical condition, including physical pain. 
    Extreme fighting. See Ultimate fighting . 
    Full-contact fighting. See Ultimate fighting . 
    Ground 'n' pound challenge. See Ultimate fighting . 
    No-holds-barred fighting. See Ultimate fighting . 
    Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or causes: 
(1)  Serious permanent disfigurement; 
(2)  Unconsciousness; 
(3)  Extreme pain; or 
(4)  Permanent or protracted loss or impairment of the function of a bodily member or organ. 
    Tough-man contest. See Ultimate fighting . 
    Ultimate fighting means a live match in which: 
(1)  Participants compete for a cash purse in any amount or a noncash purse with more than nominal value; 
(2)  Participants are not licensed as professional contestants in any state; 
(3)  Audiences are charged an admission fee; and 
(4)  Match rules permit contestants to use a combination of boxing, kicking, wrestling, hitting, punching, or other combative contact techniques. Match rules do not: 
a.  Incorporate a formalized system of combative techniques against which a contestant's performance is judged to determine the prevailing contestant; 
b.  Divide a match into two or more equal and specified time periods for a match total of no more than 50 minutes; or 
c.  Prohibit contestants from: 
1.  Using anything that is not part of the human body, except for boxing gloves, to intentionally inflict serious bodily injury upon an opponent through direct contact or the expulsion of a projectile; 
2.  Striking a person who demonstrates an inability to protect himself from the advances of an opponent; or 
3.  Direct, intentional and forceful strikes to the eyes, groin area, Adam's apple area of the neck, and temple area of the head. 
(Code 1985, § 132.60; Ord. No. 4397, 6-7-1999) 
Sec. 46-135. - Prohibited within city limits. 
    No person shall publicize, promote, conduct, or engage in an ultimate fighting match within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 132.61; Ord. No. 4397, 6-7-1999) 
Sec. 46-136. - Right of injunction. 
    The city attorney or his designated representative may institute a lawsuit in superior court or circuit court seeking injunctive relief against any individuals violating the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 132.62; Ord. No. 4397, 6-7-1999) 
Secs. 46-137-46-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DISORDERLY HOUSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Nuisance actions, IC 32-30-6-1 et seq.; actions for indecent nuisances, IC 32-30-7-1 et seq. 

Sec. 46-156. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Disorderly house means a building, dwelling, establishment, premises, or place where prohibited conduct occurs. If the building, dwelling, establishment, premises or place is a multiple-unit dwelling or residence, hotel, or motel, or commercial or office building, this definition includes only the dwelling unit, room, or suite of rooms in the hotel or motel, office rooms, or suite, or store in which prohibited conduct occurs. 
    Occupant means any person over 16 years of age whose domicile is the property upon which the prohibited conduct has been found to have occurred. 
    Prohibited conduct means activities occurring in violation of the statutes or ordinances related to any of the following: 
(1)  Gambling, as defined in IC 35-45-5-1; 
(2)  Battery, as defined in IC 35-42-2-1; 
(3)  Contributing to the delinquency of a minor, as defined in IC 35-46-1-8; 
(4)  Resisting law enforcement, as defined in IC 35-44-3-3; 
(5)  Disorderly conduct, as defined in IC 35-45-1-3; 
(6)  Criminal recklessness, as defined in IC 35-42-2-2; 
(7)  Prostitution, as defined in IC 35-45-4-2; 
(8)  Patronizing a prostitute, as defined in IC 35-45-4-3; 
(9)  Discharge of firearms, as prohibited by section 46-5; 
(10)  Loud and raucous noise, as prohibited by chapter 30, article V, constitutes prohibited conduct whenever the city has obtained a judgment or judgments upon three or more citations for violations of chapter 30, article V against a particular person living within a building, dwelling, establishment, premises, or place within a calendar year. Further, for purposes of this section, when the fine for a loud and raucous noise citation is paid, either in whole or in part, the person or entity paying the citation is deemed to have violated chapter 30, article V and such a payment constitutes a judgment with respect to that particular citation. 
(Code 1985, § 135.01; Ord. No. 4196, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 46-157. - Public nuisance. 
    Whenever prohibited conduct, as defined herein, occurs in or upon a building, dwelling establishment, premises, or place, the building, dwelling establishment, premises, or place is deemed to be a disorderly house and constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Code 1985, § 135.02; Ord. No. 4196, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 46-158. - Notice to abate. 
(a)  Whenever the police department has probable cause to believe that prohibited conduct has occurred in or upon a building, dwelling, establishment, premises, or place, the city shall notify the legal owner of the property as determined by the records of the assessor's office of the county; any party with an equitable interest in the property, provided that such equitable interest is recorded; and the occupants of the property that the building, dwelling, establishment, premises, or place is a disorderly house and as such constitutes a public nuisance and that the public nuisance must be abated. 
(b)  The legal owner of the property, any party with an equitable interest in the property, and the occupants of the property are deemed responsible for any and all prohibited conduct occurring upon the premises. 
(Code 1985, § 135.03; Ord. No. 4196, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 46-159. - Manner of serving notice. 
    Notice shall be provided to the legal owner of the property, any party with an equitable interest in the property, and the occupants of the property in the following manner: 
(1)  Sending a copy of the notice to abate by registered or certified mail to the residence, or certified to the residence or place of business or employment of the person to be notified, with return receipt requested; 
(2)  Delivering a copy of the notice to abate personally to the person to be notified; or 
(3)  Leaving a copy of the notice to abate at the dwelling or usual place of abode of the person to be notified. 
(Code 1985, § 135.04; Ord. No. 4196, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 46-160. - Injunctive relief. 
    Whenever prohibited conduct occurs in or upon a building, dwelling, establishment, premises, or place after notice to abate the nuisance has been provided pursuant to section 46-158, the city attorney may file a civil action to abate or enjoin the nuisance and to collect fines for violations of this article. 
(Code 1985, § 135.05; Ord. No. 4196, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 46-161. - Eviction proceedings as a defense. 
    No owner/landlord shall be charged with the violation of this article if the person: 
(1)  Has, within 30 days of receipt of a notice to abate as set forth in section 46-158, instituted an eviction proceeding in a court of competent jurisdiction against the tenant or occupant in question; and 
(2)  Has completed the same within 90 days of commencement. 
(Code 1985, § 135.06; Ord. No. 4196, 8-4-1997) 
Secs. 46-162-46-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Actions for use of property constituting drug nuisance, IC 32-30-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 46-191. - Purpose. 
    The common council finds it to be in the best interests of the residents of the city and the general public to provide for the regulation of conduct it deems to be offensive; to prevent vice, disorder and immorality; and to promote public peace, health and safety, and to this end, the council enacts this article. 
(Code 1985, § 134.01; Ord. No. 3554, 12-2-1991) 
Sec. 46-192. - Permitting use of real estate for illicit drug activity. 
    No person who has legal or equitable ownership of real estate located in the city shall knowingly allow that real estate to be used as a site for any use or sale of illicit narcotics or controlled dangerous substances, after having received written notice pursuant to IC 36-7-9-25 from the city or any agency or political subdivision thereof that a present occupant or tenant of that property has been using or selling illicit narcotics or controlled dangerous substances at that property. A legal or equitable owner of the real estate is deemed to have knowledge of the activity upon receipt of notice as set forth herein. 
(Code 1985, § 134.02; Ord. No. 3554, 12-2-1991) 
Sec. 46-193. - Notice. 
    Notice is deemed to be given to the owner, upon receipt of notice, as indicated in section 46-192, by the owner of record pursuant to the county assessor's office records. 
(Code 1985, § 134.03; Ord. No. 3554, 12-2-1991) 
Sec. 46-194. - Discrimination forbidden. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to encourage or authorize the discrimination by lessors against any person based upon race, creed, religion, sex, age or national origin. It is the intent of this article to hold persons accountable for acquiescing or participating in the continued use of their property as the location of illegal drug activity, after having received notice as set forth in section 46-192. 
(Code 1985, § 134.04; Ord. No. 3554, 12-2-1991) 
Sec. 46-195. - Criteria for establishing violations. 
    The conviction for violation of this article will be determined by the appropriate judicial authority based upon the totality of the circumstances present; including, but not limited to, the owner having received notice as set forth in this article consisting of one of the following activities: 
(1)  Conduct of tenants and their visitors as observed by the lessor or officials, agencies or political subdivisions of the city; 
(2)  Information regarding suspected illegal activities on that property received by the owner or equitable owner as determined by the records of the county assessor's office from third parties, including other tenants of the property or persons residing or working in the vicinity of the property, and investigated by an agency or political subdivision of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 134.05; Ord. No. 3554, 12-2-1991) 
Sec. 46-196. - Eviction proceedings as a defense. 
    No person shall be charged with the violation of this article if the person: 
(1)  Has, within 30 days of receipt of notice of criminal activities as set forth in section 46-192, instituted an eviction proceeding in a court of competent jurisdiction against the tenant in question; and 
(2)  Has completed the same within 90 days of commencement. 
(Code 1985, § 134.06; Ord. No. 3554, 12-2-1991) 
Sec. 46-197. - Multiple-unit dwellings. 
    In the case of a multiple-unit dwelling, the only person necessary to name in an eviction proceeding is the person occupying the actual unit involved with the activity suspected and/or the person suspected of the activity described herein. 
(Code 1985, § 134.07; Ord. No. 3554, 12-2-1991) 
Chapter 50 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Recreation facilities and programs, IC 36-10-2-2; General Park and Recreation Law, IC 36-10-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 50-1. - Park hours. 
(a)  The hours of operation of each municipal park shall be established by the board of parks and recreation. The parks superintendent shall post the hours of operation in a conspicuous place in each park, and shall be authorized to enforce the closing of the parks by appropriate measures. He shall also be authorized to grant extensions of the closing time to the holders of park use permits for special functions as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  The hours of operation of the municipal golf course shall be established by the board of parks and recreation, but the parks superintendent shall have the power and authority to close the municipal golf course, its grounds and roadways, to public usage after the closing hour of the municipal golf course, and to enforce such closing in the same manner as herein provided for other parks. 
(c)  Any person in a park after the park has closed will be asked to leave. Failure to do so will be considered a violation of this chapter and is subject to penalty. 
(Code 1968, tit. 330, art. II, § 1; Code 1985, § 98.01; Ord. No. 1329, 6-7-1965; Ord. No. 1568, 5-4-1970; Ord. No. 4949, §§ 1, 2, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 50-2. - Use of park facilities. 
(a)  Whenever any person desires to use the park facilities for a particular purpose, such as a sporting show or event, picnic, party, reception, theatrical performance, or entertainment, such person shall make application for a permit to use the park facilities to the parks superintendent. Such application shall be on a form furnished by the parks superintendent. 
(b)  The parks superintendent shall be authorized to grant such application and issue the permit if it appears that such use will not interfere with the general usage of the park facilities by the public. An indemnity bond or proof of insurance to protect the city from any liability of any nature and to protect city property from damage may be required by the parks superintendent as a condition to issuing any park use permit. 
(Code 1968, tit. 330, art. II, § 2; Code 1985, § 98.02; Ord. No. 1329, 6-7-1965; Ord. No. 1568, 5-4-1970) 
Sec. 50-3. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person in a city park to: 
(1)  Drive or park any automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, other motor vehicle, or bicycle in any park except on properly designated and maintained roadways and parking areas, or to operate such vehicles through parks after closing hours, except on duly dedicated streets and avenues which extend through the parks and are not closed by the park director. 
(2)  Willfully or recklessly mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace, or remove any building, bridge, table, bench, fireplace, receptacle, railing, fence, monument, waterline or fountain, electric light or fixture, sign, notice, or other structure, equipment, facilities, or park property of any nature. 
(3)  Throw, deposit, or cause or allow to be thrown or deposited on any park property any rubbish, garbage, trash, leaves, ashes, paper, debris, glass, metal, rubber, or other refuse of any nature; or to throw, deposit, discharge, or otherwise cause to be placed in the waters of any pool, pond, river fountain, or other body of water in or adjacent to any city park any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of the waters. 
(4)  Bring in, deposit, dump, or otherwise leave on park property any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, refuse, or garbage. No refuse or trash generated by park users while in the parks shall be left on the park grounds in the open or placed in any water in or contiguous to the park grounds, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles whenever provided; and whenever proper receptacles are not provided, such trash and refuse shall be carried away from the park by the persons responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(5)  Pick, cut, break off, or otherwise disfigure any flower, tree, shrub, or plant growing in the parks. 
(6)  Launch boats into any waterway in or contiguous to park property except at properly designated boat launching ramps or areas. 
(7)  Bring any controlled substance as defined by the laws of the state, drugs, beer, ale, or any other alcoholic beverage, into any park or consume, or have in their possession, or sell, give away, or handle, any controlled substance, or intoxicating alcoholic beverages, except on written permission from the board of parks and recreation or its duly authorized agents. 
(8)  No person shall sleep or protractedly lounge on the seats, or benches, or other areas including parking lots; or engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language; or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to a breach of the public peace in the public parks. 
(b)  Any gift or donation to honor individuals or events must have written approval from the parks superintendent prior to installation. Any unapproved installation shall be removed by park personnel. 
(Code 1968, tit. 330, art. II, § 3; Code 1985, § 98.03; Ord. No. 1329, 6-7-1965; Ord. No. 1568, 5-4-1970; Ord. No. 3212, 10-17-1988; Ord. No. 5412, § 1, 8-19-2013) 
Sec. 50-4. - Swimming prohibited in nondesignated areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a city park to swim, wade, or otherwise enter into the manmade waterways in city parks, except for those areas specifically designated for swimming. This prohibition shall include, but not be limited to, the Battell Park Rock Garden and the Robert C. Beutter Riverfront Park Raceway. 
(Ord. No. 4948, § 1, 7-5-2005) 
Chapter 54 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 54-1-54-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRIVATE DRIVES OR ENTRANCES 

Sec. 54-19. - Conformance to standards established by city engineer. 
(a)  The city engineer shall determine and establish the requirements, regulations, and restrictions for any private entrances, driveways, curbs, and approaches as may be necessary to provide for drainage to the highways, streets, and alleys, preservation of the highways, streets, and alleys and conservation and preservation of parking space thereon, and for the safety and convenience of traffic on the highways, streets, and alleys. 
(b)  All existing private entrances, driveways, curbs, and approaches connecting with any highway, street, or alley in the city, and all future construction, alteration, and changes of private entrances, driveways, curbs, and approaches shall be subject to, comply with, and conform to the plans, regulations, and specifications prepared by the city engineer, which are on file in his office for public inspection. 
(c)  Should any existing private entrances, driveways, curbs, or approaches connecting with any highway, street, or alley in the city, as they now exist not conform and comply with the plans, specifications, and regulations herein referred to, the owner or occupant of the abutting property shall remove, or move part or all, or relocate or conform the private entrances, driveways, curbs, and approaches to this article when requested to do so by the city engineer within 60 days from the date of the notification. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. I, §§ 2, 7; Code 1985, § 101.01; Ord. No. 981, 7-19-1948) 
Sec. 54-20. - Permit required. 
    No person shall construct any private entrance, driveway, or approach connecting with any highway, street, or alley in the city, nor shall any curb along such highway, street, or alley be cut or removed without the written permit of the city engineer, and then only in accordance with the regulations and requirements of the city engineer. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. I, § 1; Code 1985, § 101.02; Ord. No. 981, 7-19-1948) 
Sec. 54-21. - Permit application; fee. 
(a)  Whenever any person desires to construct, alter, or change any private entrance, driveway, curb, or approach as herein mentioned, he shall make application to the city engineer on a form to be furnished by the city engineer, giving such information as the form may require. It shall be the duty of the city engineer to make, or cause to be made, an inspection of the proposed work, to certify compliance with the plans, regulations, and specifications as set forth in this article. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city engineer to issue to each applicant a permit to make the improvement. The permits shall be printed in a convenient book form, one detached and given to the person procuring it, and the other to be filed in the office of the city engineer. 
(c)  All permits shall be limited to and expire after 30 days from the date of the issuance thereof. 
(d)  The city engineer shall collect from the applicant a fee of $5.00 for each permit issued for a residential driveway and a fee of $25.00 for each permit issued for a commercial driveway. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. I, §§ 8, 9; Code 1985, § 101.03; Ord. No. 981, 7-19-1948) 
Sec. 54-22. - Construction; bond. 
    All work on private entrances, driveways, curbs, and approaches shall be done under the supervision and to the satisfaction of the city engineer. The entire expense of constructing the private entrance, driveway, curb, and approach shall be borne by the person to whom the permit is given. The city engineer is authorized to require before granting the permit that a sufficient bond be given or a cash deposit be made with the city engineer to insure the carrying out of the terms of the permit, which bond or deposit shall be returned when the requirements of the permit have been met. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. I, § 3; Code 1985, § 101.04; Ord. No. 981, 7-19-1948) 
Sec. 54-23. - Maintenance. 
(a)  The owners or occupants of the abutting property shall maintain and keep in repair all private entrances, driveways, curbs, and approaches thereto, but no private entrances, driveways, curbs, and approaches shall be constructed or maintained in such a manner as to obstruct or interfere with the highway, the traffic thereon, or with any drain which has been constructed on or which serves the highway. 
(b)  When any highway, street, or alley in the city is constructed or reconstructed, the construction of public road approaches and existing private approaches, together with the drainage structures required for its protection, shall be included as a part of the improvement of the highway or city-maintained street. The city engineer may require the changing of the location of any existing driveway in the interest of the safety of the motoring public when the street or alley is constructed or reconstructed, and the person owning or occupying the abutting property shall make the changes in location under the direction of the city engineer. Upon the completion of the street or alley, the owner or occupant of adjoining lands shall keep in repair all private approaches or driveways from the street or alley. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. I, §§ 4, 5; Code 1985, § 101.05; Ord. No. 981, 7-19-1948) 
Sec. 54-24. - State highways excluded from regulations. 
    This article shall apply only to highways, streets, and alleys maintained by the city and shall not apply to state highways. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. I, § 6; Code 1985, § 101.06; Ord. No. 981, 7-19-1948) 
Secs. 54-25-54-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREET BARRICADES 

Sec. 54-52. - Barricading streets for cleaning, maintenance and improvement. 
(a)  Streets and highways within the corporate limits of the city shall, if necessary for the efficient cleaning, maintenance, and improvement of the same, be at the direction of the city street commissioner barricaded and closed to public use as is hereinafter specified, until the completion of the cleaning, maintenance, and improvement operation. 
(b)  Barricades shall clearly announce to the public the intention of the city to clean, maintain, and improve the streets and highways, which shall be sufficient notice to the public to refrain from parking any automobiles, other mechanical units or objects about and along the thoroughfares and shall, further, be sufficient notice to the owners of any automobiles, mechanical units, or any objects of whatever description parked thereon to remove or cause the removal of them within 12 hours from the time of placement of the barricades. Traffic through and along the thoroughfares may be restricted and stopped entirely during the cleaning, maintaining, or improving operation when the restriction may, in the opinion of the street commissioner, be necessary to the proper and safe conduct of the street cleaning, maintaining, or improving in progress, all of which shall be clearly announced to the public on signs specifying the restrictions pertinent to the particular street being cleaned, maintained, or improved, attached, or placed in proximity to the barricade or other obstruction fixed along the street. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. II, § 1; Code 1985, § 101.15; Ord. No. 1209, 7-11-1960) 
Sec. 54-53. - Interference with barricade, continued use of street prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb or interfere with any barricade. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or permit the continued use of any street or highway barricaded pursuant to the terms of this article for the parking of any automobile, mechanical unit, or object of whatever description. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street or highway for the purpose of vehicular traffic when it is restricted against such use pursuant to the terms hereof. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting physicians or operators of emergency vehicles engaged in the conduct of their duties from parking within the barricaded areas. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. II, § 3; Code 1985, § 101.16; Ord. No. 1209, 7-11-1960) 
Sec. 54-54. - Impoundment of vehicles in violation. 
    Any automobile, mechanical unit, or other object parked or located on any street or highway that is barricaded, following the time limit in section 54-52, shall, upon the direction of the city street commissioner, be forcibly removed and impounded. The costs and charges incurred for removal and impoundment shall be the sole responsibility of the owner. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. II, § 2; Code 1985, § 101.17; Ord. No. 1209, 7-11-1960) 
Secs. 54-55-54-81. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STREET IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 54-82. - Record of grades adopted by reference. 
    The record of grades and the record of widths of sidewalks and information heretofore collected by the city engineer and recorded in the records known as the record of grades are adopted. The schedule therein filed and the record of grades shall remain on file in the city engineer's office. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. III, § 1; Code 1985, § 101.25; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-83. - Grade datum for street grades. 
    The grade datum for all grades shall be at the intersection of curbs at the southeast corner of Main Street and Lincolnway in the city. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. III, § 3; Code 1985, § 101.26; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-84. - Interference with grade stakes or other guards prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, interfere with, or meddle with any grade stakes, fences, lights, or other guards placed by the city, its agents, or employees, or where the same is required to be placed by any person by any ordinance of the city in the streets, alleys, and public places of the city, or to destroy or deface, mutilate, change, modify, injure, or remove, or to in any manner interfere or meddle with street signs placed by the city on its streets, alleys, and public places, or to destroy, deface, or mutilate, remove, or injure any seats, benches, stands, signs, monuments, or other property erected in the streets or alleys, parks or buildings, or other public places of the city. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. III, § 4; Code 1985, § 101.27; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-85. - Procedure for excavating in streets. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any person making an application for a permit pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
    City means the City of Mishawaka, Indiana, and its authorized agents. 
    City engineer means the person serving as city engineer, his office or authorized representative.
