    Emergency means any unforeseen circumstances or occurrences, the existence of which constitutes a clear and immediate danger to the health and welfare of citizens, or which cause the interruption of services being furnished by a public utility when said interruption would cause a gross inconvenience or endanger the health and welfare of citizens. 
    Excavation means any opening, excavation, or tunnel in or under the surface of any street. 
    Excavation permit means the authorization issued by the engineer, in accordance with this section, to make an excavation in a street. The excavation permit shall consist of a placard, issued by the engineer, which shall be conspicuously displayed at the site of the excavation, such as in the window of a building or contractor's vehicle window located on the site. 
    Street means a public street, public highway, public alley, public easement, public right-of-way, public road, or all other public lands under the jurisdiction of the city. 
(b)  Requirements for a permit. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to excavate in any street for the purpose of laying any gas, water or sewer mains, or connections, or to open the street for any other purpose without first filing his application with the city engineer. 
(2)  The application shall contain or be accompanied by the following items: 
a.  A drawing including at least the following information: 
1.  Location and purpose of the excavation. 
2.  North arrow and graphic scale. 
3.  Dimensions of opening. 
4.  Patching material and method. 
5.  Expected dates of commencing and completing work, including any pavement replacement. 
6.  Name of contractor, emergency telephone number, and name of contact person. 
7.  Any additional information that may be deemed necessary by the engineer to protect the city's right-of-way and the motoring public. 
b.  A bond issued by a surety company in an amount equal to the cost of the proposed excavation but not less than the penal sum of $5,000.00, payable to the city. The bond will be released upon completion and acceptance of the work by the engineer, but not before one year after completion of the work. 
c.  Proof that the following insurance will be in effect during the entire time required to perform and complete all the work for which the permit is to be issued: 
1.  Workman's compensation insurance to cover any and all of the applicant's employees working at the site of the excavation; 
2.  Public liability bodily injury insurance of not less than $100,000.00 for injuries, including accidental death, to any one person, and subject to the same limit for each person in an amount of not less than $200,000.00 on account of one accident; 
3.  Public liability property damage insurance of not less than $25,000.00; and 
4.  Automobile public liability bodily injury with $100,000.00/$250,000.00 and property damage with $25,000.00 limits. 
(3)  A separate excavation permit will be required for every 50 linear feet or part thereof. 
(4)  A fee of $10.00 shall be assessed for each excavation permit for the review of plans, existing site conditions, and to perform construction inspection. 
(5)  An excavation permit shall be issued by the engineer within a maximum of three working days after the filing of an application and bond, to allow for the engineer to review plans and existing site conditions. 
(6)  An excavation permit will become null and void if work is not begun within 30 days from the date of issue and will expire on the date given in the application as the expected completion date. The applicant shall give the engineer one working day's notice before beginning the work, if work is not started within three working days of the date given in the application. 
(7)  In the event of an emergency, when an excavation permit cannot be obtained from the engineer, the excavation may proceed provided that the person who made the emergency excavation shall apply for an excavation permit immediately upon the first day of business of the city offices, as previously set forth herein, and additionally will submit a written explanation of the reason or nature of the emergency. 
(8)  It will not be necessary for the city water or electric departments to post a bond or pay the permit fee; however, all expenses of excavating, repairing, and replacing any and all pavement and other existing materials shall be paid for by the respective departments. An excavation permit, however, must be applied for by all departments as set forth herein, just as for any other individual. 
(9)  An applicant for an excavation permit shall agree to save the city harmless from any and all costs, damages and liabilities which may accrue to any person as a result of work performed under an excavation permit issued as set forth herein. 
(c)  Restrictions and requirements. 
(1)  Except in the event of an emergency, excavation permits will not be issued between the dates of November 15 and April 1, inclusive. In the event of weather and ground conditions, particularly with respect to freezing, being favorable for excavation, the engineer may issue an excavation permit, with possible additional restrictions, for dates between November 15 and April 1. 
(2)  Excavations requiring complete transverse cuts of any street shall be bored or tunneled. Transverse open cuts, in specific cases, where reasonable due to the nature and volume of the traffic and existing site conditions, shall be on approval of the engineer. 
(3)  All work shall comply with the engineering standards of the city, as adopted by the board of public works and safety and all necessary traffic control, warning and protection devices shall be in accordance with the state manual on uniform traffic control devices for streets and highways. 
(4)  The applicant will be required to obtain all existing utility locations and will be responsible for the protection of all utility lines, services and appurtenances. (Call 1-800-382-5544, within Indiana or 1-800-428-5200, from outside Indiana, for utility locations two working days before beginning excavation.) 
(d)  Penalties. Any person found to be in violation of any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to the following actions: 
(1)  If found guilty by the appropriate court having jurisdiction, shall be fined according to section 1-7. 
(2)  Repeat violations will be handled at the discretion of the engineer and may result in the refusal to issue any excavation permit to the applicant. 
(3)  Failure to complete work in the proper manner shall result in the engineer taking necessary steps to remedy the defects, and the costs thereof shall be recovered by an action on the bond before any court of competent jurisdiction. Also, the applicant may be subject to the suspension of applications for an excavation permit for a period of one year from the date of bond action. 
(Code 1985, § 101.28; Ord. No. 3302, 8-7-1989) 
Sec. 54-86. - Excavations, street obstructions to be lighted. 
(a)  Any person making any excavation as provided in this section, or any excavation made within the city limits in any street or sidewalk, or near to or adjoining any street or sidewalk, shall mark the excavation with a flashing light placed during each night of the existence of the excavation, at the point where the excavation approaches the nearest street or sidewalk. The flashing light shall be lighted at dark and kept burning until daylight to indicate the locality of the excavation. 
(b)  Any obstruction placed in any street or on any sidewalk within the limits of the city, including piles of dirt, lumber, or other material temporarily placed in the street during the construction or repairing of any building, or part of building, shall be marked during the night by a flashing light so placed as to indicate the obstruction to persons passing along the street or sidewalk. The flashing light shall be lighted at twilight and kept burning until dawn each night during the existence of the obstruction. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. III, §§ 6, 7; Code 1985, § 101.29; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Secs. 54-87-54-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SIDEWALK AND CURB IMPROVEMENT 

Sec. 54-116. - Improvement permit. 
(a)  Application; required information. Whenever any person desires to construct any cement sidewalks or curb within the corporate limits of the city, he shall apply to the city engineer stating the number of feet to be constructed together with the number of the lot and description of the tract of land or parcels of ground to be improved. 
(b)  Issuance. It shall be the duty of the engineer to issue to each applicant a permit to make the improvements. The permits shall be printed in a convenient book form, one copy to be retained by the city engineer in the book, and one detached and given to the person procuring the same. No permit shall be issued on any street, alley, or other public place after the board of public works and safety has passed a resolution advertising for bids for the improvement. 
(c)  Time limit; renewal. All permits shall be limited to 30 days from the date of the application, and permits on streets, alleys, and other public places covered by any improvement resolution shall be limited to the date of the resolution advertising for bids. Permits may be renewed if the board of public works and safety has not passed a resolution covering the improvement. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. IV, § 1; Code 1985, § 101.40; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-117. - Permit fee. 
    The city engineer shall collect from the applicant a permit fee of $5.00. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. IV, § 2; Code 1985, § 101.41; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-118. - Bond. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct a cement walk and curb shall give a bond in the sum of $1,000.00 signed by two freeholders or a surety company satisfactory to the board of public works and safety, to secure the faithful performance of the contract and to guarantee the work for a period of one year from the date of the completion of the work. Thirty days after the date of the application shall be considered the date of completion unless otherwise ordered by the common council. 
(b)  Any sidewalk showing cracks and other defects due either to defective material or bad workmanship shall be removed and replaced by entirely new blocks at any time during the guarantee period, if so ordered by the board of public works and safety or city engineer. 
(c)  If at any time during the guarantee period, the contractor fails or refuses to make the necessary repairs or reconstruction after ten days' notice has been given by mail by the board of public works and safety or city engineer to do so, the board of public works and safety shall proceed to have the repairs or reconstruction done in a correct manner and by whosoever they may desire and charge the cost of the work, together with 20 percent additional to cover the cost of supervision and inspection of the work, the whole sum to be recovered by suit on the bond of the contractor or the party taking out the permit for the improvement. However, in case of entire reconstruction, the work may be let by contract. The cost of the reconstruction shall be paid by the city and recovered by suit from the party or firm in whose name the permit was taken out, or from the bondsmen. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. IV, § 4; Code 1985, § 101.42; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-119. - Sidewalk specifications. 
    Unless otherwise ordered by the board of public works and safety, the width of the sidewalk shall be four feet, eight inches, and when the walk and curb are together, the width shall be five feet, two inches. Prior to construction, the plans shall be submitted to and approved by the city engineer, and the sidewalk shall be constructed in conformance with the specifications set forth at section 604 of the state highway standard specifications, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1985, § 101.43) 
Sec. 54-120. - Curb specifications. 
    Prior to any construction of cement curb, plans therefor shall be submitted to and approved by the city engineer, and the curb shall be constructed in conformance with section 605 of the state highway standard specifications, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1985, § 101.44) 
Sec. 54-121. - Preliminary and primary assessment roll to be prepared after completion of improvement. 
(a)  As soon as any contract for the improvement of any street or alley has been completed, it shall be the duty of the committee on streets and alleys together with the city civil engineer to prepare a final estimate and a preliminary or primary assessment roll with the names of property owners and a description of the property abutting on and adjacent to the improvement which is liable to assessment. They shall set opposite each name and description the total assessment, if any, against each piece of property, and file the final estimate and preliminary or primary assessment roll with the city clerk on or before the first regular or special meeting after the contract is completed. If it is impossible for the committee and engineer to complete the final estimate and preliminary or primary assessment for the first regular or special meeting, the common council at the meeting may grant the committee and engineer such further time as in the opinion of the common council may be necessary. 
(b)  Upon the filing of the final estimate and preliminary or primary assessment roll with the city clerk, the clerk shall present it to the common council for its consideration as a preliminary or primary assessment roll and final estimate, and the common council shall consider it and pass a resolution adopting a final estimate and preliminary or primary assessment roll. The resolution shall also authorize and instruct the city clerk to give the necessary notice to the property owners of a hearing of special benefits on the improvements. 
(Code 1968, tit. 480, art. IV, §§ 7, 8; Code 1985, § 101.45; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Secs. 54-122-54-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC UTILITIES 

Sec. 54-141. - Installation procedure when street or public way is improved. 
    Whenever the board of public works desires to improve any street, alley, or other public place by paving it, and further desires to adopt an improvement resolution to that effect, the board is authorized to include in the improvement resolution the installation of sewer, water, gas, wire, and other connections as may be deemed necessary to accommodate the abutting property along the street, alley, or public place. In addition, the improvement resolution shall have affixed thereto the necessary plans and specifications designating the material to be used in the sewer, water, gas, wire, and other connections, the number and location thereof, and the manner of paying for them from the main to a point inside the curbline. However, this article shall not prevent any owner of any abutting property from making the connections and installations if he makes and completes them in accordance with the plans and specifications for such connections and installations as designated by the board within 20 days from the date of the confirmation of the resolution. 
(Code 1968, tit. 400, § 1; Code 1985, § 101.55; Ord. No. 597, 5-19-1926) 
Sec. 54-142. - Cost of connections; assessment. 
    The cost of making the connections by the board of public works shall be considered part of the cost of the permanent improvement project and shall be so assessed against the abutting properties that are benefited. 
(Code 1968, tit. 400, § 2; Code 1985, § 101.56; Ord. No. 597, 5-19-1926) 
Secs. 54-143-54-166. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ACTIONS RELATED TO BUILDINGS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-167. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    When any person or entity holding a permit issued pursuant to section 54-188 shall violate any provision of this article, such permit shall be subject to revocation by the city building commissioner and such person or entity shall be liable to the city in an amount as prescribed in section 2-2(b) pertaining to ordinance violations, or section 1-7 pertaining to the general penalty 
(Code 1985, § 96.99; Ord. No. 3436, 11-19-1990) 
Secs. 54-168-54-187. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MOVING BUILDINGS 

Sec. 54-188. - Permit required. 
    Before any building or other structure is or shall be moved along any route within the corporate limits of the city, a permit for that purpose shall be issued by the building commissioner in accordance with the provisions hereinafter recited. 
(Code 1968, tit. 210, § 1; Code 1985, § 96.01; Ord. No. 1203, 2-15-1960) 
Sec. 54-189. - Application; fee. 
(a)  Before a permit is issued, application therefor shall be filed with the building commissioner. The application shall include dimensions defining the extreme height, width, and length of the structure, when mounted; the route over which it will be moved; a plot plan showing the structure in its proposed new location; and affidavits from all public utility companies, railroads, service companies, and municipal departments having facilities along the proposed route, certifying that the owner of the structure proposed for removal has deposited with the company, agency, or department satisfactory surety to cover the cost of any damage or changes in facilities resulting from the moving of the structure over the intended route. The application shall also have attached detailed plans and specifications representing the final plans of the owner for the structure once deposited in its proposed new location, which shall conform in all things with the requirements of article V of chapter 101, pertaining to property maintenance and all ordinances amendatory thereof or supplemental thereto. 
(b)  Before the application shall be processed by the building commissioner, the applicant shall pay an application fee of $25.00 to the office of the commissioner simultaneously with its filing, together with whatever expenses may be chargeable for abstracting costs incurred in connection with the investigation by the building commissioner of the proposed new location, for restrictions, or other covenants running with the land which may affect the general welfare. These expenses shall be paid by the applicant prior to the public hearing described in section 54-190. 
(Code 1968, tit. 210, §§ 2, 3; Code 1985, § 96.02; Ord. No. 1203, 2-15-1960) 
Sec. 54-190. - Public hearing required; exceptions. 
(a)  A hearing before the board of public works and safety upon the merits of the application for a permit shall be had and held within ten days after its filing with the building commissioner for the purpose of hearing evidence relating to the movement of the structure proposed for removal insofar as it may affect the health, safety, and general welfare of the community. Following due notice via ordinary United States mail by the office of the commissioner to the title-owners, as they appear of record in the offices of the Penn Township, St. Joseph County Assessor, of not less than two-thirds of the land fronting on both sides of the street for a distance of 500 feet in each direction from the proposed new location, advising of the time, place, and purpose of such hearing, the board shall enter into a determination concerning the issuance of such permit. The decision shall in all things bind the building commissioner in connection with the issuance or refusal of the permit. 
(b)  In the event of the issuance of the permit, the building commissioner shall inspect or cause the inspection of the structure at its new location to be made within 90 days from the date of the issuance to determine the qualifications under the requirements of article V of chapter 101, or any ordinances amendatory thereof or supplemental thereto; whereupon a report of his findings shall be made to the board of public works and safety for further notice, if necessary, pursuant to the conditions of law in such cases. 
(c)  The building commissioner may, upon proper application, issue permits without the necessity of a public hearing and the affidavits aforesaid when the structure to be moved is proposed for removal on the bed of a truck or trailer; provided the extreme dimensions of the structure, when mounted for moving, shall not exceed 14 feet in height, 14 feet in width, and 20 feet in length. The building commissioner may, further, issue permits without the necessity of a public hearing when the structure to be moved shall be proposed for removal to a location outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1968, tit. 210, §§ 4, 5; Code 1985, § 96.03; Ord. No. 1203, 2-15-1960) 
Sec. 54-191. - Filing of bond required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to move or cause to be moved, any structure upon or along any street within the limits of the city, without having first filed with the building commissioner a bond approved by the city controller in the sum of $5,000.00, indemnifying the city against any and all loss, cost, or damage to its streets caused by the moving of the structure. It shall be further conditioned that the person will indemnify and pay all damages to any person or property caused by any negligent act or omission in the moving of the structure. 
(Code 1968, tit. 210, § 6; Code 1985, § 96.04; Ord. No. 1203, 2-15-1960) 
Sec. 54-192. - Safety procedures. 
    In the event that any building is moved pursuant to the provisions of this division, the holder of the permit obtained pursuant to section 54-188 shall be required to: 
(1)  Within 48 hours after the time that the building being moved has been lifted from its old foundation from which it is being moved, completely fill in with suitable fill material subject to the approval of the city building commissioner the old foundation or excavation from which the building being moved has been removed; 
(2)  Until said old foundation or excavation shall be so filled in, erect around such old foundation or excavation a sturdy fence of sufficient materials, size and construction, subject to the approval of the city building commissioner, suitable to prevent any person, particularly children, from falling into the foundation hole or excavation, or from otherwise being injured there. Such fence must fully enclose the foundation hole or excavation from the time that the building being moved has been lifted from its former foundation until the time that the foundation hole or excavation has been completely filled in as required in subsection (1) of this section, excepting for such time or times when the holder of the permit, his contractor, employees or agents is or are personally present at the site of the foundation hole or excavation; and 
(3)  Maintain a fence of sufficient materials, size and construction, subject to approval of the city building commissioner, around the base of the building being moved after it has been lifted from its foundation and until it is permanently installed upon its new foundation in the location to which it is being moved, sufficient to keep any person, particularly children, from gaining access under the building being moved. Such fence shall completely enclose the base of the building being moved whenever it is not permanently mounted on a foundation except during any time when the holder of the permit or his contractor, employees or agents are personally present at the site of the building being moved; and 
(4)  Complete the moving of the building in question by permanently placing the building on its new foundation in the location to which it is being moved within ten days after the date of issuance of the permit pursuant to section 54-188. 
(Code 1985, § 96.19; Ord. No. 3436, 11-19-1990) 
Secs. 54-193-54-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 54-221. - Numbering system of city. 
(a)  All blocks and lots in the city shall be numbered north and south from Lincolnway, and east and west from Main Street, beginning with the number 100 for blocks, and designating the successive blocks by successive hundreds. On all streets each 22 feet front shall have one number. The lots shall be numbered north and south from Lincolnway, and east and west from Main Street south side, the number of the lot corresponding with the number of the blocks, the first lot in block 100 to be numbered 101, and so on; the design being that the hundreds shall indicate the blocks, and the units the house numbers in the block. One hundred numbers are reserved for each block, and even numbers on north-south streets are to be on the east side of the streets. On east-west streets the even numbers shall be on the north side. 
(b)  The city engineer shall assign a number to each lot or part of a lot fronting on any street, avenue, or public place, according to the plan, assigning odd numbers to one side and even numbers to the other side of the street, avenue, or public place; and assigning a number to each 22 feet of land fronting north and south, or as near to that number of feet as practicable. He shall keep a record of all such numbers so assigned. 
(Code 1968, tit. 220, § 1; Code 1985, § 96.15; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-222. - Owner to place numbers; when city to number. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of every house or business place in the city shall place the number assigned to his lot or part thereof, by the city engineer in a conspicuous place on the side of or above the front door of that house or building. The number shall consist of figures not less than three inches in length, and be so made or marked as to be distinctly or easily read. 
(b)  After the time limited in this division for placing numbers on houses or buildings, the city shall place a number upon any house or building not numbered as aforesaid and recover the cost from the owner or occupant in a civil action. 
(Code 1968, tit. 220, §§ 2, 4; Code 1985, § 96.16; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-223. - Numbering new buildings. 
    Every owner or occupant of any building hereafter erected in this city shall, within 30 days after the erection thereof, place a number thereon according to the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1968, tit. 220, § 3; Code 1985, § 96.17; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Sec. 54-224. - Unlawful to alter or deface numbers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take down, alter, deface, destroy, or cancel any number assigned to be placed upon any building; or to place, substitute, or permit to be placed or substituted an erroneous or improper number to be retained upon any building. 
(Code 1968, tit. 220, § 5; Code 1985, § 96.18; Ord. No. 300, 8-6-1906) 
Chapter 58 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to and including a highway when at least 50 percent of the frontage of the territory for a distance of at least 500 feet is occupied by buildings in use for business. 
    Central traffic district means all streets and portions of streets within the area described as follows: All that area bounded by Lawrence Street on the north, Cedar Street on the east, the New York Central right-of-way on the south, and West Street and Liberty Drive on the west. 
    Commercial vehicle means every vehicle designed, maintained, or used primarily for the transportation of property or passengers for hire. 
    Private road or driveway means a way or place in private ownership that is used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner but not by other persons. 
    Residence district means the territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business district when the property on the highway for a distance of at least 500 feet is primarily improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
    Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and that is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times. 
    Sidewalk means the part of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Stand or standing means the halting of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. I, §§ 1, 2; Code 1985, § 70.01; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Similar state law definitions, IC 9-13-2 et seq. 
Sec. 58-2. - Traffic engineer. 
(a)  Office established. The office of city traffic engineer is established. The city engineer shall serve as city traffic engineer in addition to his other functions, and shall exercise the powers and duties with respect to traffic as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Duties. It shall be the general duty of the city traffic engineer to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices, to conduct engineering analyses of traffic accidents, and to devise remedial measures, to conduct engineering investigations of traffic conditions, to plan the operation of traffic on the streets and highways of this city, to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. II, § 10; Code 1985, § 70.11; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-3. - Traffic accidents; investigations and reports. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the police department to investigate traffic accidents, to arrest, and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to the accidents. 
(b)  Whenever the accidents at any particular location become numerous, the police chief or his designee shall cooperate with the city traffic engineer in conducting studies of the accidents and determining remedial measures. 
(c)  The police department shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports. The reports shall be available for the use and information of the city traffic engineer. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. II, §§ 4-6; Code 1985, § 70.14; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- City may require accident reports, IC 9-26-1-7. 
Sec. 58-4. - Drivers' files to be maintained. 
(a)  The police department or the traffic division thereof shall maintain a suitable record of all traffic accidents, warnings, arrests, convictions, and complaints reported for each driver. The reports shall be filed alphabetically under the name of the driver concerned. 
(b)  The division shall study the cases of all the drivers charged with frequent or serious violations of the traffic laws or who are involved in frequent traffic accidents or any serious accident, and shall attempt to discover the reasons therefor, and shall take whatever steps as may be lawful and reasonable to prevent the same or to have the license of such persons suspended or revoked. 
(c)  The records shall accumulate during at least a five-year period and from that time on the records shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent five-year period. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. II, § 7; Code 1985, § 70.15; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-5. - Temporary or experimental regulations. 
    The city traffic engineer, with the prior consent of the common council by its resolution, is empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter by making and enforcing temporary or experimental regulations to cover traffic patterns, movements, or special traffic conditions. The resolution of the common council approving the temporary or experimental regulation shall be in effect for such period of time as the resolution designates. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. II, § 13; Code 1985, § 70.17; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 2575, 12-6-1982) 
Sec. 58-6. - Obedience to traffic code required. 
    It is a punishable violation for any person to do any act forbidden or to fail to perform any act required by this chapter or traffic provisions of state law. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. III, § 2; Code 1985, § 70.26; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1960, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-7. - Public employees to obey traffic regulations. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government, the state, the county, or the city. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. III, § 6; Code 1985, § 70.27; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Public employees to obey regulations, IC 9-21-1-6. 
Sec. 58-8. - Vehicle impoundment. 
(a)  Members of the police department are authorized to remove a vehicle from a street or highway to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the police department, or otherwise maintained by this city under the circumstances enumerated as follows: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended on any bridge, viaduct, or causeway, or in any tube or tunnel where the vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(2)  When a vehicle on a highway is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
(3)  When any vehicle is left unattended on a street and is parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(4)  When any vehicle is parked in a "no parking" zone as set forth in article IX of this chapter. 
(b)  Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street as authorized in this section and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle the name and address of the owner thereof, the officer shall immediately give or cause to be given notice in writing to the owner of the fact of removal and the reasons therefor, and of the place to which the vehicle has been removed. In the event any vehicle is stored in a public garage, a copy of the notice shall be given to the proprietor of the garage. 
(c)  Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street under this section and does not know and is not able to ascertain the name of the owner, or for any other reason is unable to give notice to the owner as provided in subsection (b) of this section, and in the event the vehicle is not returned to the owner within a period of three days, the officer shall immediately send or cause to be sent a written report of the removal by mail to the state department whose duty it is to register motor vehicles, and shall file a copy of the notice with the proprietor of any public garage in which the vehicle may be stored. The notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, time, and place from which removed, the reasons for the removal, and the name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(d)  The owner of the impounded vehicle shall be liable to the city, to the extent of the market value of the vehicle, for all of the costs incidental to the removal, storage, and disposal of the vehicle. This amount shall be recoverable in an action at law by the city against the vehicle owner. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XVII, § 14; Code 1985, § 70.28; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 3084, 8-18-1988) 
State Law reference- Officer authorized to remove certain vehicles, IC 9-21-16-4. 
Sec. 58-9. - Motor vehicle inspection fee. 
(a)  The police department is empowered to and shall collect a fee of $5.00 for services associated with the inspection of motor vehicles made under IC 9-17-2-12 pursuant to IC 9-29-4-2. 
(b)  The revenue generated by virtue of this section shall be delivered in a timely fashion to the city controller, who shall then deposit said revenue in a separate vehicle inspection fund. 
(c)  All revenue generated by virtue of this section shall be from time to time appropriated by the common council only for local law enforcement continuing education purposes. 
(Code 1985, § 70.29; Ord. No. 3249, 2-21-1989) 
Sec. 58-10. - Penalty. 
    Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this traffic code shall be punished by a fine as prescribed in section 1-7. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XVII, § 1; Code 1985, § 70.99; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 2823, 10-21-1985) 
Secs. 58-11-58-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC RULES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-39. - Use of coasters, roller skates, and the like. 
    No person shall operate or ride a scooter, skateboard, roller skates, in-line skates, coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device on any city street except while crossing a street at a crosswalk. When so crossing, the person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. III, § 5; Code 1985, § 71.002; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 4223, 10-20-1997) 
State Law reference- Rights and duties of pedestrians, IC 9-21-17-1 et seq. 
Sec. 58-40. - Unlawful riding on vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall ride on any vehicle or any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. III, § 4; Code 1985, § 71.003; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-41. - Opening, closing vehicle doors. 
    No person shall open the door of a motor vehicle on the side available to moving traffic unless and until it is reasonably safe to do so, nor shall any person leave a door open on the side of a motor vehicle available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers or freight. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VIII, § 9; Code 1985, § 71.005; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-42. - Use of streets by certain vehicles. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine and designate those heavily traveled streets on which shall be prohibited the use of the roadway by motor-driven cycles, bicycles, horsedrawn vehicles, or other nonmotorized traffic, and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(b)  When signs are so erected giving notice thereof, no person shall disobey the restrictions stated on the signs. 
(c)  No person shall drive or operate, or cause to be driven or operated, any road engine, traction engine, tractor, or other heavy vehicle having lugs or spikes attached to the tread or wheels thereof on any asphalt-paved street or alley in the city limits. However, the engine or vehicle may be operated on such streets and alleys if guards or protectors are used to prevent damage to the pavement by the lugs or spikes. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VIII, § 21, tit. 510, art. XV, § 3; Code 1985, §§ 71.00, 71.006; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Authority to limit use by certain vehicles, see IC 9-20-1-3(a)(1). 
Sec. 58-43. - Backing of vehicles. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not back such vehicle unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VIII, § 8; Code 1985, § 71.008; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-44. - Obstructing intersections and crosswalks prohibited. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VII, § 8; Code 1985, § 71.009; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-45. - Parades. 
    No procession or parade except one of the forces of the United States Army or Navy, the military forces of this state, and the forces of the police and fire departments shall occupy, march, or proceed along any street except in accordance with a permit issued by the board of public works and safety and such other regulations as are set forth herein which may apply. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VIII, § 6; Code 1985, § 71.043; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate procession, IC 9-21-1-3(a)(3). 
Secs. 58-46-58-61. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUSES 

Sec. 58-62. - Buses not to block streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any bus to stop within an intersection or on a crosswalk for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VIII, § 15(b); Code 1985, § 71.035; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-63. - Bus stops. 
(a)  Authority is vested in the city traffic engineer to designate bus stops at such locations and in such number as may be necessary and of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. Every such bus stop shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(b)  The operator of a bus shall not stop the bus at any place for the purpose of taking on or discharging passengers other than at a bus stop so designated as provided herein, except in case of emergency. 
(c)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle at an authorized bus stop so designated as provided herein, or between the right curb and any such stop, except that the operator of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop thereat for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the discharge of passengers or the pick up of passengers then in readiness at the curb. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VIII, § 17; Code 1985, § 71.036; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-64. - Buses not to pass on city streets. 
    No driver of a bus traveling on and over any city street shall overtake and pass any motor vehicle traveling on four or more wheels when such vehicle is in motion and moving in the same direction. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XV, § 4; Code 1985, § 71.037; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Secs. 58-65-58-117. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 

Sec. 58-118. - Conformance to state specifications. 
    All traffic-control signs, signals, and devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by the state department of highways or resolution adopted by the common council of this city. All signs and signals required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this division shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. IV, § 2; Code 1985, § 71.050; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- City's authority to maintain traffic control devices, IC 9-21-4-3. 
Sec. 58-119. - Authority of city to install. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer shall place and maintain traffic-control signs, signals, and devices when and as required under the traffic code of this city to make effective the provisions of the traffic code, and may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic code of this city or under state law or to guide or warn traffic. 
(b)  A permanent written record of the traffic control devices as so authorized shall be kept by the city traffic engineer. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. IV, § 1; Code 1985, § 71.051; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Local traffic control devices, IC 9-21-4-3. 
Sec. 58-120. - Presumption of legality. 
(a)  Whenever official traffic control devices are placed in position approximately conforming to the requirements of this traffic code, such devices shall be presumed to have been placed by the official act or direction of lawful authority, unless the contrary shall be established by competent evidence. 
(b)  Any official traffic control device placed pursuant to the provisions of this traffic code and purporting to conform to the lawful requirements pertaining to such devices shall be presumed to comply with the requirements of this traffic code, unless the contrary shall be established by competent evidence. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. IV, § 4; Code 1985, § 71.052; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-121. - Crosswalks. 
    The city engineer is hereby authorized to do the following: 
(1)  Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines on the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may deem necessary. 
(2)  Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. IV, § 13; Code 1985, § 71.058; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish crosswalks, IC 9-21-17-4. 
Sec. 58-122. - Quiet zones. 
    Whenever signs are posted indicating a quiet zone, no person driving or operating a vehicle within any such zone shall sound a horn or other audible warning device on the vehicle, except in an emergency. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VIII, § 20; Code 1985, § 71.059; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-123. - Traffic lanes. 
    The city engineer is authorized to mark traffic lanes on the roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is deemed necessary. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. IV, § 14; Code 1985, § 71.060; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-124. - Interference with official traffic control devices. 
    No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down, or remove any official traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal or any inscription, shield, or insignia thereon, or any other part thereof. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. IV, § 10; Code 1985, § 71.062; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Secs. 58-125-58-146. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TURNING MOVEMENTS 

Sec. 58-147. - Turning markers or signals at intersections. 
(a)  The city engineer is authorized to place pavement markers or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at the intersections, and such course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to or be other than as prescribed by law or ordinance. 
(b)  When authorized pavement markings, or other indicators are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of the indicators. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. V, § 2; Code 1985, § 71.071; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate traffic via control signals, IC 9-21-1-3(a)(2); turns at intersections, IC 9-21-8-21. 
Sec. 58-148. - Restricted turn signals. 
(a)  The city engineer is authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right-turn, left-turn, or U-turn, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. 
(b)  The making of those turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs, or the signs may be removed at the times the turns are permitted. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. V, § 3; Code 1985, § 71.072; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate traffic at intersections, IC 9-21-8-21. 
Secs. 58-149-58-179. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ONE-WAY STREETS AND ALLEYS 

Sec. 58-180. - Official traffic control device required. 
    Whenever any ordinance of the city designates any one-way street or alley, the city engineer shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulation shall be effective unless the signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where the movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VI, § 1; Code 1985, § 71.080; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-181. - Authority to restrict traffic direction during certain periods. 
(a)  The city engineer is authorized to determine and designate streets, parts of streets, or specific lanes on which vehicular traffic shall proceed in one direction during one period and the opposite direction during another period of the day, and shall place and maintain appropriate markings, signs, barriers, or other devices to give notice thereof. The city traffic engineer may erect signs temporarily designating lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction, regardless of the centerline of the roadway. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle in violation of such markings, signs, barriers, or other devices placed in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VI, § 3; Code 1985, § 71.081; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish one-way streets, IC 9-21-1-3(a)(4). 
Secs. 58-182-58-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - INTERSECTIONS 

Sec. 58-201. - Through streets. 
(a)  Those streets and parts of streets described in section 58-553 are declared to be through streets for the purpose of this division. 
(b)  Whenever any ordinance of this city designates and describes a through street, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to place and maintain a stop sign or, on the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation at any intersection, a yield sign on each and every street intersecting the through street unless traffic at the intersection is controlled at all times by traffic-control signals. At the intersection of two such through streets or at the intersection of a through street and a heavy traffic street not so designated, stop signs shall be erected at the approaches of either of the streets as may be determined by the city engineer on the basis of an engineering and traffic study. A permanent written record of all such signs as placed shall be kept by the city engineer. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VII, §§ 1, 2; Code 1985, § 71.093; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-202. - Hazardous intersections. 
    The city engineer is authorized to determine and designate intersections where particular hazards exist on other than through streets and to determine the following: 
(1)  Whether vehicles shall stop at one or more entrances to any such intersection, in which event he shall cause to be erected a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required; or 
(2)  Whether vehicles shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles on a different street at such intersection, in which event he shall cause to be erected a yield sign at every place where obedience thereto is required. A permanent written record of all such signs as placed shall be kept by the city engineer. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VII, § 3; Code 1985, § 71.094; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-203. - All-way stop intersections. 
    Whenever an intersection is designated in section 58-554 as an all-way stop intersection, stop signs shall be erected at each entrance to the intersection, and for the purpose of this designation, it shall be immaterial that one or more of the intersecting streets may elsewhere be declared to be a through street. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. VII, § 3; Code 1985, § 71.095; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Secs. 58-204-58-229. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-230. - Application of parking provisions. 
    The provisions of this article prohibiting the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XIV, § 1; Code 1985, § 72.01; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-231. - Regulations imposing time limits. 
    The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XIV, § 2; Code 1985, § 72.02; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Secs. 58-232-58-255. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 58-256. - Parking not to obstruct traffic. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle on a street, other than an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(b)  All vehicles shall be parked within 12 inches of a curb or the edge of the roadway, and the front of the parked vehicle shall face in the direction of the flow of the adjoining lane of traffic. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, § 2, art. XIV, § 6; Code 1985, § 72.13; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-257. - Parking in alleys. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, § 3; Code 1985, § 72.14; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-258. - Parking for sale or maintenance of vehicle prohibited. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on any roadway for the principal purpose of displaying the vehicle for sale or hire or greasing or repairing it, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, § 5; Code 1985, § 72.15; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-259. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
(a)  The city engineer is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking on either or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property when the parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(b)  When official signs are erected indicating no parking on either side of a street adjacent to any school property as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, § 6; Code 1985, § 72.16; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-260. - Parking on narrow streets. 
(a)  The city engineer is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking on any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed 20 feet, or on one side of a street as indicated by such signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed 30 feet. 
(b)  When official signs prohibiting parking are erected on narrow streets as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle on any such street in violation of any sign. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, § 7; Code 1985, § 72.17; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-261. - Parking on one-way streets and roadways. 
(a)  The city engineer is authorized to erect signs on the left-hand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles, and when the signs are in place, no person shall stand or park a vehicle on the left-hand side in violation of any such sign. 
(b)  In the event a highway includes two or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction on any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle on the left-hand side of the one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine when standing or parking may be permitted on the left-hand side of any such one-way roadway and to erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, §§ 8, 9; Code 1985, § 72.18; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-262. - Parking in hazardous or congested areas. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine and designate by proper sign places not exceeding 100 feet in length in which the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b)  When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized herein, no person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(c)  The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine and designate, by proper sign, places not exceeding 250 feet in length in which the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles at signalized intersections would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, § 10; Code 1985, § 72.19; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 3680, 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 58-263. - Parking vehicles used for transporting flammable liquids. 
(a)  No tank vehicle which is used for the transportation of flammable liquids shall be left unattended on any street or alley in the city. This shall not prevent a driver from the necessary absence from the truck in connection with the delivery of his load, except that during actual discharge of the liquid some responsible person shall be present at the vehicle, nor shall it prevent stops for meals during the day or at night if the street is well lighted at the parking place. 
(b)  Tank vehicles containing flammable liquids shall not be parked out of doors in the city at any one point for more than one hour, except off the streets, and at least 25 feet from any building used for assembly, institutional, or recreational occupancy. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, § 11; Code 1985, § 72.21; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-264. - All-night parking prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle for a period of time longer than one hour between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. of any day, except physicians on emergency calls on any city street when signs are posted advising of the parking limitation. 
(b)  No trailers or commercial vehicles shall park overnight on any city street. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XII, § 4; Code 1985, § 72.22; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-265. - Angle parking. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer shall determine on what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets. Nonetheless, angle parking shall not be indicated on any federal-aid or state highway within the city unless the state department of highways has determined by resolution or order entered in its minutes that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. 
(b)  Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive on the left side of the street. 
(c)  On those streets which have been signed or marked by the city traffic engineer for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by the signs or markings. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XI, §§ 2, 3; Code 1985, § 72.23; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parking, IC 9-21-1-3(a)(1). 
Sec. 58-266. - Parking fines. 
(a)  In the case of any violation of any section or provision of this chapter prohibiting or restricting parking on any public street or in any municipal parking lot, the fine for each violation shall be $10.00 if the fine is paid within five days of the date of the issuance of the parking citation, and the fine shall be $25.00 if paid more than five days after the date of issuance of the parking citation. The fine shall be paid to the city police department at the city police station, accompanied by the original or a copy of the written citation issued for the improper parking violation. 
(b)  In the case of any parking violation for vehicles parked in a designated fire lane, the fine for each violation shall be $50.00 if the fine is paid within ten days of the date of the issuance of the parking citation, and the fine shall be $75.00 if paid more than ten days after the issuance of the parking citation. The fine shall be paid to the city police department at the city police station, accompanied by the original or a copy of the written citation issued for the improper parking violation. 
(Ord. No. 5242, § 1, 12-7-2009) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 5242, adopted Dec. 7, 2009, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 58-266 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 58-267-58-293. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LOADING ZONES 

Sec. 58-294. - Designation of loading zones. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating them and stating the hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XIII, § 1; Code 1985, § 72.30; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-295. - Permits for loading zones. 
(a)  Required. The city traffic engineer shall not hereafter designate or sign any loading zone on special request of any person unless the person applies for a permit for the zone and for two signs to indicate the ends of each zone. 
(b)  Annual fee; conditions on use of signs. The city traffic engineer on granting a permit and issuing the signs shall collect from the applicant and deposit in the city treasury a service fee of $10.00 per year or fraction thereof. In addition, he may by general regulations impose conditions on the use of the signs and for reimbursement of the city for the value thereof in the event of their loss or damage, and their return in the event of misuse or on expiration of permit. 
(c)  Expiration. Every such permit shall expire at the end of one year. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XIII, § 2; Code 1985, § 72.31; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-296. - Standing in loading zones. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to the loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pick-up and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. The stop for loading and unloading of materials shall not exceed 30 minutes unless the freight loading zone is designated herein in section 58-576. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XIII, §§ 3, 4; Code 1985, § 72.32; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-297. - Designation of public carrier stops and stands. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized and required to establish bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands, and stands for other passenger common-carrier motor vehicles on public streets in places and in numbers as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. Every such bus stop, bus stand, taxicab stand, or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XIII, § 5; Code 1985, § 72.33; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Sec. 58-298. - Buses, taxicab stands regulated. 
(a)  The operator of a bus shall not stand or park the vehicle on any street at any place other than a bus stand so designated. 
(b)  The operator of a bus shall not stop the vehicle on any street at any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage other than at a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone so designated as provided herein, except in case of an emergency. 
(c)  The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop, bus stand, or passenger loading zone on a public street in such a manner that the bus when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage shall be in a position with the right front wheel of the vehicle not further than 18 inches from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(d)  The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than in a taxicab stand so designated as provided herein. This provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(e)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XIII, §§ 6, 7; Code 1985, § 72.34; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1963, 6-7-1976; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976) 
Secs. 58-299-58-329. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PARKING FOR PERSONS WITH PHYSICAL DISABILITIES 

Sec. 58-330. - Persons who qualify as physically disabled. 
    The following persons qualify as being physically disabled for purposes of this division, and shall be entitled to all of the parking privileges authorized by this division: 
(1)  A person who has been issued disabled veteran registration plates by this state or any other state, and who displays the plates. 
(2)  A person who has been issued a special registration place or placard bearing the international wheelchair symbol by this state or any other state, or any political subdivision of this state, and who displays the plate or placard. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XX, § 1; Code 1985, § 72.40; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 2647, 12-5-1983) 
State Law reference- Disabled veterans' parking, IC 9-18-18-1 et seq.; parking facilities for persons with physical disabilities, IC 5-16-9-1 et seq. 
Sec. 58-331. - Designation of handicapped parking spaces. 
(a)  The board of public works and safety is authorized to designate spaces for handicapped parking which is reserved for persons with physical disabilities. 
(b)  Upon designation of a space for handicapped parking, the curb shall be painted blue and a vertical sign measuring at least 48 inches from the base of the sign shall be installed bearing the international wheel chair symbol and the words as follow: 
"HANDICAPPED PARKING ONLY 
DISABLED PLATE OR PLACARD REQUIRED 
ALL OTHERS WILL BE TOWED AWAY AT 
OWNER'S EXPENSE" 
(c)  All angle parking spaces so designated shall be at least 13 feet wide. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XX, § 2; Code 1985, § 72.41; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 2647, 12-5-1983) 
State Law reference- Reserved parking spaces to bear international symbol of accessibility, IC 5-16-9-2(e). 
Sec. 58-332. - Parking limits. 
    The provisions of this division shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe any parking time limit imposed by any ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XX, § 3; Code 1985, § 72.42; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 2647, 12-5-1983) 
Sec. 58-333. - Use of designated parking spaces by nonhandicapped persons. 
    Any motor vehicle found parking in a space designated for handicapped parking which does not display a disabled veteran registration place or a special registration plate or placard bearing the international wheelchair symbol shall be fined $50.00 for the first 30-minute violation, and $50.00 for the second 30-minute violation. The vehicle shall be towed at the owner's expense if found to be in violation longer than one hour. If the fine issued pursuant to this section is not paid within ten days, the fine shall be increased to $75.00 for each violation not paid within ten days of its issuance. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. XX, § 4; Code 1985, § 72.43; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 2647, 12-5-1983; Ord. No. 3413, 9-4-1990; Ord. No. 5242, § 2, 12-7-2009) 
Secs. 58-334-58-354. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PARKING PERMITS 

Sec. 58-355. - Issuance of municipal parking lot permit. 
    A municipal parking lot permit shall be issued under the authority of the city board of public works on an annual basis for an annual fee and upon such other terms and conditions as the board of public works may from time to time determine, and shall be issued through such city agency or department as the board of public works may designate from time to time. The holder of such a municipal parking lot permit shall be entitled to park his vehicle to which the municipal parking lot permit was issued in any unused parking space which is not specifically reserved by posted sign, indicating an exclusive reserved parking space, in any of the municipal lots listed in section 58-575(6) in which parking by municipal parking permit is allowed as indicated above. The holder of such a municipal parking lot permit shall not be entitled to the exclusive use of any particular parking place or to the exclusive use of any space in any particular parking lot. 
(Code 1985, § 72.55; Ord. No. 2858, 2-18-1986) 
Sec. 58-356. - Issuance of exclusive reserved parking space permits. 
    The city board of public works is hereby authorized, from time to time, to issue one or more exclusive reserved parking space permits and to designate one or more parking spaces in municipal off-street parking lot number three as an exclusive reserved parking space. Each such exclusive reserved parking space shall be designated by a prominent sign, which shall state the person or entity for whom or for which said space is exclusively reserved. No person other than the holder of such exclusive reserved parking space permit shall be entitled to the use of such space for the parking of any vehicle which such exclusive permit holder may designate from time to time, in writing, to the city agency or department authorized by the board of public works and safety to issue municipal parking lot permits. The board of public works is authorized to issue such exclusive reserved parking space permits in consideration of the lease or sale of real estate to the city for use as a municipal off-street parking lot or for any other municipal purpose, such exclusive reserved parking space permit to be issued under such terms and conditions as the board of public works may negotiate pursuant to such lease or purchase agreement. 
(Code 1985, § 72.56; Ord. No. 2858, 2-18-1986) 
Secs. 58-357-58-385. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BICYCLES; MOTORCYCLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate bicycles, IC 9-21-1-3(a)(9); operation of bicycles and motorized bicycles, IC 9-21-11-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 58-386-58-413. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BICYCLE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 58-414. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means any vehicle coming within the common definition of the term, having one or more wheels, including, but not limited to, unicycles and tricycles. 
    Downtown business district means the real estate within the city, described as follows: commencing at the intersection of the centerline of Grove Street and Elizabeth Street; thence east, along the centerline of Grove Street to the centerline of Sarah Street; thence South along the centerline of Sarah Street to the south right-of-way line of Mishawaka Avenue; thence west along the south right-of-way line of Mishawaka Avenue to the east right-of-way line of Main Street; thence south along the east right-of-way line of Main Street to the north bank line of the St. Joseph River; thence south and east along the north bank line of the St. Joseph River to the center-line of Race Street (if projected north to the river's south bank); thence south along the (extended) centerline of Race Street to the centerline of Lincolnway East; thence west along the centerline of Lincolnway East/US 33 to the centerline of Church Street; thence south along the centerline of Church Street to the centerline of Third Street; thence east along the centerline of Third Street to the centerline of Race Street; thence south along the centerline of Race Street to the centerline of Fourth Street; thence west along the centerline of Fourth Street to the east right-of-way line of Church Street; thence south and east of along the east right-of-way line of Church Street to the south right-of-way line of the Conrail Railroad; thence west along the south right-of-way line of the Conrail Railroad to the centerline of Spring Street; thence north along the centerline of Spring Street to the centerline of Fourth Street; thence west along the centerline of Fourth Street to the centerline of West Street; thence north along the centerline of West Street to the south right-of-way line of Lincolnway West; thence west and southwest along the south right-of-way line of Lincolnway West to the east right-of-way line of Logan Avenue; thence north along the east right-of-way line of Logan Avenue to the north bank line of the St. Joseph River; thence east and north east along the north bank line of the St. Joseph River to the east right-of-way line of Forest Avenue; thence north along the east right-of-way line of Forest Avenue to the south right-of-way line of Mishawaka Avenue; thence east along the south right-of-way line of Mishawaka Avenue to the centerline of Elizabeth Street; thence north along the centerline of Elizabeth Street to the point of beginning. 
    Public property means any real estate in which any governmental entity or subdivision has any right, title or interest, whether by ownership, lease or otherwise. This shall include, but not be limited to, streets, sidewalks, parks, municipal parking lots and the riverwalk. 
    Public right-of-way means any real estate dedicated for or over which the public has a general right of passage. 
    Rollerskate/rollerblade means a shoe, boot, or mechanism designed to attached to a shoe, boot or a person's foot, which is mounted upon one or more wheels. 
    Scooter means any wheeled vehicle which is propelled by motor or by its operator by resting a portion of his body weight upon the vehicle while pushing against the ground with another portion of the operator's body. The term shall not include a wheelchair or wheelchair-like device used primarily to aid disabled individuals' mobility. 
    Skateboard means a board consisting of manmade or natural material which is mounted upon wheels. 
(Code 1968, tit. 510, art. X, §§ 14(a), (c), 19; Code 1985, § 73.02; Ord. No. 1360, 5-2-1966; Ord. No. 1968, 7-6-1976; Ord. No. 1974, 8-2-1976; Ord. No. 3389, 7-2-1990; Ord. No. 4950, §§ 1, 2, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 58-415. - Riding on roadways, bicycle paths, and sidewalks.
